Most of the same principals apply, instead of trading inside out, by which I mean being in the middle of the screen and trying to determine the trend and going with it to the bottom or top of the screen, (whiplash land) we try to go from the outside in, ie. 4H system. In the 60x90 or 180x100 we start closer to the center and use the natural up and down motion (the edges of whiplash land) of Forex to take profit. It is kinda of a reverse Fib levels. Instead of following the trend and trying to reenter the dips and hope the trend continues, we use these retraces to take profit knowing, except in extreme cases, they will always happen. The farther from the median we get the closer we are to getting our profit.

I posted this on my other thread but it shows why the 40MA BB trading system should be very successful. It also shows you how you survive with the 2.4.2 system on the 4 runners. This obviously would apply to any currency pair.   
  
There is one part of my system that if you can handle the runners, you will be very successful. Here is the eur/jpy for the last 5 months. There are 28 potential trades you could have gotten if you just played the BB band. Enter sell on top and buy on the bottom. Of the 28 24 were immediate winners and 4 were runners. I marked the 4 runners with an x and the # of pips on each run. If you can grasp this one thought, understand it, learn to trade it, this system will be very successful for you. If you can zero out or minimize the loss of the 4 runners you can see very good profits.   
  
Two of the runners were easy to handle -223 which is two levels, no problem, -342 which would be 2 or 3 levels. They bounced back nicely and would be easily 0 out or minimally profitable. Now the other two. If you follow my recovery system. You would take a L1 loss on each one and then 0 out the rest. The last one is the one I am in now and I have taken a level 1 loss and now am waiting to 0 out the other 3 levels. That is the plan so if this last one follows form this is what your trading could look like on the Eur/Jpy.  
28 trades, 24 winners, 2 losing trades with 3L break evens and 2 trades that may or not be minimal winners or losers. I like those odds.   
  
What looks ugly right now is when one pair is running like this, all the pairs of that group will run. The JPY is running across the board but the eur/jpy is in the worst shape right now. The others are still only 2 or 3 levels or already had a retrace. So that is something you will see and learn over time. My solution to that problem is two fold. Either use enough money to not have margin problems or use a limited number of mixed currencies to cover your trading.   
  
So if you can learn this one thing you can be very successful with this system. Do you have the patience and margin to ride out the band runs? Do you have the trading skill to do this? If you do you can see how your losses can be minimal and your winners very successful, you will love this system  
  
I also marked two retraces on this last run in yellow and I could have gotten out. I did think about it at the time but I chanced the change of direction and it was the wrong decision. It is not that I didnt have opportunity to escape this run I just didnt think the retraces were going to be that small. These are decisions you make that sometimes work and sometimes dont. Either way price will not keep going up forever, I am guaranteed a retrace again but this time I will take it and go for the smallest loss I can get. So if you can grasp what you see here and understand how it works you can be profitable.

To get around FIFO IBFX says as long as your lot sizes are different you can close in any order you want. So instead of levels of 5, 5, 5 I am experimenting with 3,5,8 which is a 16 commitment over a 15 commitment. To find numbers that work try this program and get multiples that would get you closer to breakeven. The problem you have is if you only try for 50 pips off of a 200 reentry you will need to multiply by 4 to make the third level profitable. That also gives you a much higher risk. The deeper you go in the trade the bigger the retrace must be to get where you want to go. So on 5.5.5 each level I need a 200 retrace to break even at level 3. At a 1.6 multiplier or levels 3,5,8 I only need a retrace of 138 to break even. That is a 35% retrace on a -400 move. That is a reasonable number to expect. Fibo numbers give retracement at 38.2% so I think that formula would work. Anyway here is Frostcalls formula program that works in Excel. See if you can find numbers that work for you. I have it set at 3,5,8 to show you how they look. The program does not add the spread so take that into your thinking when you develop numbers.

I posted this on the other thread but if you get caught on the wrong side of a trade this week using the system, especially if a country makes an interest rate change, just close the trade and follow the trend. If they dont change look for a big move and then a big retrace the next day, could be very profitable. Anyway here is my note:  
  
Well this is going to be an exciting week with prices bouncing all over the place. Interest rate news   
MON AUD (expecting an increase)  
WED USD  
THURS EUR, GBP  
  
Recently no news or no change in the interest rate has been very exciting. There have been big moves on currencies, some moving over 300 pips in a matter of hours, when they havent changed their rates and long trends lasting weeks when they do. I would not want to take the 60x90 into these news stories. I dont think it has enough range to handle these kind of moves when there are interest rate changes. I will not even use my 180x100 during this week. I will be using the 40MA BB on pairs not effected by the news. If you are going to trade this week do not play a lot of one kind of currency. In other words dont have 5 AUD pairs going at once. Maybe 2, same with all the others. Take your 2 or 3 favorites and trade them.   
  
_**VERY IMPORTANT. MAJOR NEWS ALWAYS TRUMPS INDICATORS.**_ If any country changes its interest rate just follow the trend. They probably will run 2-3 weeks in one direction so follow it. If they dont change there have been big moves for about a 24-36 hour period. So trade with care.

Finding a top or a bottom of a move is like finding a needle in a haystack so we search for it. In a ranging market Sto and BB work great. If trending then we look for the blue sto crossing the MACD. However, I am not going to sit and stare at a screen all day looking for it. We want to stay out of the trade until there is a move downward. A 3x3 is fairly accurate but 20% of the time it will enter too early. A 3x3 is approximately the same time the white sto will cross the 15 or 85 line. So the logic is I want a definite downturn before I enter and the sto crossing the 15/85 is a good place to start. The 20% of the time it is wrong we multi level the entrance. That is the theory. Once we are in overbought and oversold territory, price will move only so far before it retraces for some reason. The exception is very big news stories or a fundamental change in the currency IE interest rate changes. We watch out for those two things we are in good shape on almost every trade. If we get into a bad trade we try to retrace our way as close to 0 as we can get so we get to keep our profits.

There are two important things about interest rates. If they change, they fundamentally change the direction or continuation of a currency. This may affect a currencies movement for days or even weeks. As you may have noticed the last AUD change sent price up for 3 weeks straight with very little retracement.   
  
Second there is associated news that comes out with it based on the interest rate change or non change. So even though the interest rate may not change, the currency will move based on associated news. Last year we had a change on the NZD rate that moved the market but several hours later, based on that change, the credit rating changed which made the NZD shoot hundreds of points. That secondary story caused me to take one of my biggest losses last year. That news story was not on the FF calendar but greatly affected price action. So that is why I am so cautious around interest rate changes, it affects many other areas that may not be readily seen or known as a trader.   
  
So as you can see I am very cautious around these events. Even though most of the time the market does not move that much, it is when there is a surprise and you are on the wrong end, your account can be damaged very quickly.

The EA sets the TP, SL, etc. at the time of the trade so if you change the EA it does not change the old trade because all its parameters were set at the time the trade was entered. In other words it placed at the server or your broker all the parameters. If you change the EA parameters that does not change the existing trade at your broker. You will have to change the original trade manually. However, if you change let us say the distance to the next reentry from 200 to 150 and you have kept the same magic number then the EA will reenter the trade at 150 since this is a new trade. Same thing if you change lot size, multiplication, etc. the next trade will reflect the changes. So if you start at 2x multiplication and the first trade is 2 lots then 2nd level would be 4 lots. However, if you change the multiplication to 1.5 then when it reenters the second level it will be 3 lots instead of 4 lots because you changed the parameters for the next trade. If you are at two lots on the first trade and you change the lot size to 1 lot and multiplication stays at 2x then the 2nd level would be 2 lots also, the same as the first lot, because you changed the parameters of the next trade. So EA changes do not affect the original order already placed but will change subsequent orders.

Once IBFX switches to 100:1 from 400:1 it is going to be very hard for me to stay in that 15-20% range. I am going to have to greatly increase my funds and not do as many trades at one time. I will have to play with the numbers and adjust. I will answer the other part of your question when I get home but I look at my total funds commited or my total in the lower right and compare that with my total funds in the account. So if I have 500 dollars in my account I would not want to have over 100 dollars as my DD. Once it gets past the 20% I start looking for ways to minimize my risk because once you pass that 40-50% level your funds can disappear very quickly and you have no room to manuever in adding levels. With IBFX you can have up to 3 accounts. I use two of them for trading and one for reserve funds in case I need some extra money quickly. If you tranfer funds from one account to another IBFX usually does this in a matter of minutes for you. I did that in the OCT. runnup when the gbp currencies ran on me. I had to add a couple of hundred so I could use my 2.4.2 recovery system successfully. After successfully minimizing those losses I dropped the number of pairs I traded and reduced the number of trades per currency I would do. That way I wont get my funds all tied up again. With this 100:1 ratio thing I will have to keep an eye onthese accounts to make sure I dont over margin them. Come the first week of December, I will reduce the number of trades I take, lessen my lot size and have my third account ready for transfers if I need. Until I get used to trading at this leaverage I will be very conservative with my funds. It is either that or send my money overseas. I am working on some improvements to lessen my DD but you never completely wipe that problem out in multi level trading.

Whenever I refer to a lot, I am referring to how IBFX defines a lot. So 1 lot equals 1 USD. 0.10 is one US dime and .01 is one US penny. If you use other currencies or brokers you will have to readjust your thinking and figures to that.   
  
If you are trained in traditional thought on Stop losses you will have a hard time swallowing my concept of trading. In reality I dont use stop losses. I only put them in my EAs to keep beginners from wiping out their accounts because they just wont close a losing trade. I space my reeentries apart 150-250 pips apart, depending on the pair traded and the nearest S/R line. I then wait for the bounce off of S/R lines and let the retrace reduce my loss to as close to 0 as I can get it and then am done with the trade. In reality I no longer ever take a stop loss except to close a 1st level trade so I can add a new 4th level. I highly recommend not ever trading more than 3 levels at one time. From my day by day trades you can watch and see how I reduce my DD and eliminate it with very little damage to my account. It is a trading skill, I dont think I have ever seen anywhere else. The bottom line is you will either understand and learn it, (you can use it with any trading system) or you will think it is non sense to trade without a defined stop loss. I have hung onto trades for as long as 3 weeks reducing the DD until I have gotten rid of it. The AUD/USD trade in Sept. is one example and the GBP/CHF in Oct. is the other. Both of those trades took around 3 weeks to reduce to almost 0 but it worked. So if you cant ever get your mind around not using well defined SL then this will be a very difficult system for you to understand and use. From the time I started trying to trade like this to really getting a recovery to work was about a year and a half. What I posted is my final results and system, you dont have to go through the long learning curve I did. But to finish this off and I am sorry if I took so long. Once a trade is 3 levels deep and the first level is around -400 pips you would drop that first level trade before taking on 4th level. That is what I call a losing trade. They dont happen very often but they do. I think in the last 3 months I might have 4 or 5 of those. Also understand the 400 pips is a guide not a hard fast rule. I see a major S/R line at the -425 or -450 mark I wont close that trade but hang onto it to see if it breaks that line first before closing it. Then I will close the 1st level and wait for a good entrance on my 4th level.

The reason I created the 3x3 EA was because I had a bad habit of entering too early in a trade. So I wait for the EA to enter. Now if you are having problems with the EA there maybe a reason. There are two kinds. 1 is for 5 digit trading companies and one for 4 digit trading brokers. IBFX demos are 5 digit and their live account is 4 digit. If you have a 4 digit EA on a 5 digit account or visa versa they will not work properly. So make sure you have the proper EA. Also, you are trading a 4H chart so trading is on a much slower pace. I have turn on the EA and it maynot enter for several days. It waits for the cross to happen first before entering. Many times that is when it opens on the other side because price has to go a ways under the line before the 3 MA crosses the line. I have some bad trading habits so that is what I use to solve one of them. Not entering too early.

The original system was set for every level to open at the same lot size, however, I have been experimenting with different lot sizes. I have done this because of NFA regs of FIFO and to improve my recovery time on multiple levels. What I am using now instead of 5,5,5 on every level, which totals 15. I use L1 3, L2 5, L3 8 which totals 16 but I dont have to wait for as big of a retrace to break even. So far I have like this much better. With the change of margin to 100:1 I am going to go to L1 2 L2 4 L3 6 which totals 12. The formula I am using is level 1 and 2 totals equal level 3. I also am going to double the size of my account and try fewer trades or only trades in the top 1/3 or bottom 1/3 of the screen. I hope to not have margin issues with this until I get used to trading at 100:1 leverage. With these changes I hope to find numbers that make it safe to trade and keep my account intact without danger of wiping it out or margin calls. I hope this helps other traders with the new NFA rules.

When you manually trade make sure you enter off of S/R lines. You can place pending orders to do that. I do very little manual trading on the original L1 entry because I cant predict an exact turn around spot. The EA at least wait until price has changed enough in one direction for a cross to happen. You will find over time that if you manually enter sometimes price will continue running for several days before it actually retraces. The 3 lines above/below the 15/85 lines or price has broken the BB band lines are signals that a trade is pending. I have used this system for several years but it was not until I added the 3x3 crossing EA that is become very profitable. I simply got into too many trades too early and then it was a battle to get out with a small profit or loss. The 3x3 EA is your trading discipline. It forces you to wait for a better entrance. It is not perfect but it trades better than I do. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

There are times I will manually enter a trade and violate one of my rules. I will do this for the AUD/NZD. I have a separate thread for that called trading the AUD/NZD successfully. I know that currency very well so I will do that. Ended up successful. What I did was add a level at the new resistance so I ended up with a very profitable trade. This jump pushed price very high on the chart and I though it was a great place to enter.   
However, I want to point something out about secondary trades. See the pic below:   
3 weeks ago there was a primary trade signal label #1 in white. Notice price is at the top of the screen and the red white and blue lines are above the 85 line.   
Numbers 2,3,4 are secondary signals because they match the #1 trade earlier so we take them. These are all excellent trades for the same reason. It is just the R,W,B lines are showing different signals. The W and B are showing trades (above 85 line) but the red line is in the center showing that price action is ranging for now.   
  
I also show a pink x where there is a primary trade signal but I did not take it because price is in the middle of the screen. We trade outside in, not inside out. The reason so many trend systems drive people crazy is they are trading in the middle of the screen and no matter what indicators maybe saying I have learned over time that price can go in any directions from there. However, when price is at the top of the screen or bottom, price is screaming to all the traders in the world SELL SELL or BUY BUY. I am just following predictable human behavior. If price does go against me, how far will price go off the screen before it stops? That is my basic logic behind this system.

No no no, The higher the leverage the better you can trade a multi level system. When you trade multi level most of the rules you learned about trading are the opposite. The lower the leverage the more money you have to risk. The higher the leverage the less money you risk. You can trade my systems at a penny broker for 500 dollars at 400:1 at 100:1 I will now need 2000. That is a higher risk not lower. I never understand why people dont understand that. At 400:1 my risk of MY MONEY is lower not higher. At 100:1 you will now have to face closing positions because of margin more often now. This is not a benefit to traders especially to newbies. They now have to risk more money to learn this business and will suffer bigger losses. The cost of people's education to learn Forex has just multiplied by 4.

I guess. When you are trained to put a stop loss 30 pips away and follow the trend it takes time to wrap your mind around multi level trading. The guy above wrote about how he got out of the negative eur/nzd trade but he nearly zeroed the trade and feels good of getting the exit. Once you develop the skill of zeroing out trades you will love the system. If you cant comprehend or cant emotionally handle the negative trades you will never handle this system. As long as you trade with small enough lots so you can handle the occasional surprise story the system will get easier. My viewpoint is that we want to enter in such an overbought or oversold area that even with a surprise story hits, we still have the confidence that price has to retrace at some point even though it may continue in its present trend. The Eur/Nzd may still continue to trend up but that does not matter to us. Price has to retrace and there are market forces that will always cause that.   
1\. Banks have to resupply themselves with the currency that they just sold out on. Banks make money exchanging money whether it is going up or down. They are not concerned with the hundredths or thousands of a penny like we are. When they exchange money they add on several pennies or even dimes as the cost of doing business. I may have to pay 695 RMB to get 100 USD dollars or I may pay 100USD to get 685 RMB. Their profit is much higher than yours or mine. When there is a run up like last week they have to go out and buy the currency they just sold to replenish their supplies. So you know the retrace has to come.   
2\. Market psychology is on your side. When price is at the top of the screen, you just cant mentally think it will keep going higher even though the fundamentals may scream it should. A certain amount of traders are going to take profit and another certain amount are going to want to do a sell. This will cause a retrace. When the Dubai story hit the news, there was a price runup even higher on the charts causing even more people to think time for profit, time to sell. Once they are done then the fundamentals will take over and price will continue up or if there was enough sell off for it to go into a downtrend.   
3\. Business deals that have gone one way like company A in country B sold a bunch of products to country C now companies in country C sell products back to Country B and the exchange of money reverses the trend. If you want to see this principle in action go to the aud/nzd on the 5M chart and watch price just bounce up and down as products are bought and sold between the two countries. Those two countries have a very unique currency action because they are both so far away from other countries, and are so similar economically that it has that unique bouncing up and down action you wont see on other currencies. But it clearly shows what I am trying to explain here in point #3.   
  
Just some thoughts.

You probably have heard me say this before but all indicators are based on MA with different kinds of Math formulas. Then they use different types ways to picture the results, lines, bars, etc. So when one shows a signal almost all will show the same signal. For example when the RSI crosses the 70 or 30 line that is about the same time it hits the top or bottom of a BB band. They just used different formulas and MA numbers to show their results or how they picture the information. So that is a very good observation. The R,W,B lines of my system use MACD and 2 STO lines. MACD is a slow indicator and is late in its signals. Stochastics are too fast and get you in too early, I have found when you combine the two, when the ones indicating too quickly (the two sto) cross the one going too slow (MACD) you have a fairly good indicator. Not perfect but close enough to signal an EA with a MA cross to get you in the trade in good shape the majority of the time. After that we cover our butts by multi level trading and if price defeats that we go to the 2.4.2 recovery system and try to 0 out the trade. Combined together, you have a system that rarely takes a big loss but wins enough, often enough that if you are ever hit with a big loss, (like I did last week with the gbp/nzd) or you needed to get out of a difficult trade (eur/nzd last week), there were more than enough winners to cover the loss. That is the philosophy of this trading system in a nutshell.

It is hard to see but price does not enter until the average of the last 3 bars is below the MA line. In other words price has to be below the MA line before the average crosses it. So if the last line is 6 the average must be below that, so if your last 3 lines are 7,8 the third number must be a 2 to get the average below 6. 17 divided by 3 is less than 6. The bigger the MA numbers are the lower price must be below the line before the average crosses it. I hope this makes sense. Its a math computation. However, by what I see from the pic price should have entered. Dont know at this point.

Here is a eur/usd secondary trade. I got +38 the last time. It retraced slightly higher and entered again. When price gets close to that support line I will take half profit and let the other half ride with a tight profitable SL of +10. I am looking for a break downward but fundamental traders are crying for dollar weakness so they will reenter at some point to move price back up again. However, just in case they are wrong I want the other half to take a shot at a nice drop just in case they give up in pushing price upwards. Just a reminder, a secondary trade is when we play close to a previous primary position. For the AUD/NZD and the EUR/USD we are playing off of last weeks primary trade high.   
  
AUD/NZD showing a quad (4) top, kind of rare. Aud is showing weakness and NZD is showing weakness so we dont have to worry about price running anywhere. If both of these currencies go weak it will be interesting to see which one loses more.

Good explanation. I think I mentioned in my book several TP places.   
1\. S/R lines  
2\. Middle or opposite BB band line.  
3\. White line on Sto is on the opposite side of when the trade happened  
4\. Blue line on Sto is on the opposite side or when the white recrosses the blue line.  
  
The most common one I use is when the white Sto Line has reached the opposite side or the next morning just before the start of the JPY session. By the end of the USA session currencies have made their run for the day and you can close or take 1/2 depending on what your info is on that pair. An exception to that rule are all AUD and NZD pairs since their markets open up near the end of the USA session. They will have a strong run there sometimes. So this comes with experience. AUD NZD pairs you will get around 50 pips, except for the gbp/nzd and eur/nzd they can run 100-300 in a day. Most other currencies you will get 50-150 in a day. As you can see I usually take my profit every day, I rarely hang on for more. That is because there are usually new pairs to trade and since we deal with retracements and price turnaround you can easily lose your profit the next day. When we trade we are getting the reversal of price exhaustion. Many times your profit will go away the next day because it will double, triple top, 1-2-3 swing trade or continue its trend. So price may reverse and take away your profit. My rule of thumb in trading is to never let a winning trade turn into a loser. I do not set my SL at 0 but put them at +10 when I move my SL up. I always want something for my effort. I cant comment on every trade but like Monday I will give you some tips once in a while. So time to learn.

The EA will do the work of entering trades for you and you need your computer on to do that. I run mine 24 hours a day but once the EA enters the trade I put the blank template back on manually do the trade after that. So my day is like this. I set my ea's to on before the jpy session. I check at lunch time and put the blank EA for the trades that have entered. I come home from work and check just before the USA open 6-8 pm China time and again just before bed 10-12 pm China time. By then I know whether a trade is good or in trouble. In the morning when I get up before the JPY session I set my 2nd levels (some of these will be pending orders set at S/R levels) and close my profits. This way I dont over trade or let price craziness get me to enter too many trades. As I get better at my own system I try to pass on the things I learned, like the USD/CHF post earlier. Why I took my profit instead of letting it run. Why I used a pending order instead to stay in the trade if it kept going south. So that is my trading day. My actual trading time is very short, 5-10 minutes. Explaining my logic to you guys is an hour or two every day. LOL. You may ask why I do this at FF. Well, this is my real reason. _**SO I STAY DISCIPLINED.**_ I will take trades I shouldnt unless I make them public. Then I will pass on some of my bad trading habits. So you guys help me stay profitable. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) thanks guys. Well, lunch is over, sorry I couldnt answer all your questions. I really appreciate some of you guys answering questions for me, this saves me a lot of time and also shows that you understand the system.

I expected some end of week profit taking but will have to wait for Monday. I like my position on every single trade. When price breaks it should be a good run. Though some news stories ran prices up or down a bit, more people are reluctant to take trades when price is at the top of the screen or bottom like they are now. There just isn't that much room even though in reality it shouldn't make any difference. I just think its human psychology at work. So I like my position on all of these trades. If a news story is positive price may move up/dosn some more but probably not that much.  
My theory is: if those same news stories that moved price up/down Friday on the USD/CHF, EUR/USD and other pairs would have moved them more if price had been in the middle of the page. I think that is human psychology at work. Only the very ardent news fan will take trades near the top of a chart other people will see price to high and be reluctant to do so.   
My thoughts for the beginning of next week are:  
Price will retrace here at the S/R of the 1D chart. We can then take our profit and if the fundamentals stay strong, price will break higher or lower but we will get our retrace here first. Often or almost every time, price tests a barrier before breaking through so we take our profit off of these bounces. If there is bad news then price will break hard in our direction and we will make a truck load. Either way I think we are in a very good win win situation.

What is divergence with MACD?? Some traders will only trade divergence, very patient trading method but when I see one I like to load up. Here are two examples of divergence with the Eur/USD over the last 3 weeks and eur/chf present divergence. The first pic (eur/usd) price double tops (yellow A1-A2) but the MACD red line goes lower, its peak point is lower than the previous peak point (yellow A1-A2) notice the resulting price drop afterwards. Nice 470+ drop. We now have the same thing (Pink B2 to B1) price goes lower but MACD red line is going higher. This is called divergence and is a good indicator that price will change directions. Good time to take the ride and look for the head and shoulder completion. Hope this is clear as mud. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) The first pic is eur/usd divergence and the second is eur/chf divergence. If you have always wanted to take a trade and hold it in profit for a couple of days this is a great time to try. I love guys who post after an event has happened this is what you should have done but I try to teach what you can do before it happens. Doesn't mean I am always right but this is a good time for a hold em strategy try. I think the dollar bears are going to buy again.

Different brokers come from different time zones in the world. For example you can start trading earlier with a AUD or NZD broker who will open up earlier than a USA or EUROPEAN broker at the beginning of a week. Different brokers will use different start times with their MT4 so some maybe +2 GMT +1 GMT 0 GMT etc. So the only way I can answer that question is to demo the different platforms and decide which one you like best. Also different brokers use different banks for their quotes so those can be different also. I use IBFX if you want to use that for a reference to compare with what you are getting.

If you follow my rules on the 2.4.2 recovery system the deepest I go on a level is around 400 pips. At that point I only close the 1st level trade and then add a new third level trade. I dont go any deeper than that. You can do the math as far as lot size and percentage of account. When I start to hit 3rd level trades I want to be 15% or less on my account. When I get to the 4th level (remember I am dropping the 1st level at that point) I dont want to be more than 20% of my account. If you are hitting higher than that then you are playing with too big of a lot size or playing with too many currency trades at one time. My totall DD for all my trades I try to keep under 1500 but that is not always possible. When I get 2500 I know I should be dropping some of my worst trades. So whatever math and leverage you need should stay in those ranges. Except on really long runs (like the eur/usd and usd/chf are doing now) I generally stay well under 1000 on my DD. 1000 DD may sound like a lot but in reality I have seen that disappear in 1-2 days when price reverses. Even as a trend trader you could probably adapt my 2.4.2 recovery system into your system. I like it so much better than using stop losses. I use S/R lines on a 4H or 1D to make my decisions on where to put my extra levels with my spacing being around 200 pips apart.

I did all three the last week of December. I was hit by the eur/cad, eur/usd, usd/jpy, usd/chf. All of them went on 3 week with no major retraces. I finally took 2300 pips in losses (I was +1300 for the month and ended up -1000). Yes I offset some of that with winners but you can see from my monthly total that it was not a good two weeks there. I finally on the eur/usd just took a loss at a minimum retrace. That was just plain ugly. As you know the long drawn out trend run that moves slowly and never retraces is the biggest killer of my systems. See the pic below as I give the history of the trade and what I did. I think the biggest disservice I have done you guys is not do a daily on my losing streak. It should have been a good teaching tool watching me handle these type of losses. I regret now not doing that. Excellent question.  
  
As you can see I had opportunities to take out that trade without a big loss but I get arrogant and think I can get out of any losing situation. That is not always true and then I end up taking a much bigger loss than I should have. I really felt with a 3 hump divergance on a 4H chart (MACD line) I was looking at a nice winner but it did not happen. 90% of the time that would be true but with the upcoming holidays there just wasn't enough trading/business going on to make it happen. Some bad decision making and ignoring some very strong fundamentals. The big drop on Dec. 17th killed me on that trade. This is the one weakness of my system and happens rarely but we must understand it does happen.

Excellent ideas, however, we in the USA can no longer hedge. I had developed a trading system buying a buy and sell at the same time. I would then take profit no matter which direction price went and using half of the winning position to close 40% of the losing position. I would then hedge again and waited until one position profited enough to take away half of a losing position. I would then try to trade out the last part of the losing position. It worked well in my testing but because hedging was banned by the NFA I was no longer able to trade. I loved hedging. I could walk away from my computer at any time and pick up the trade at another time. It gave you a chance to regroup yourself and overcome your negative thoughts and feelings. I could wait until the market gave me a better decision point to trade again. Yes I agree with your thoughts and think they are excellent. We just cant do that anymore with a USA broker and many foreign brokers dont want to take USA clients now. So we are stuck for now. Thanks for the great input.

Here is my lament about the loss of hedging and some of my thoughts about the NFA:  
  
**P. 55 post 822 I give an example of why I think the NFA are a bunch of loonies for banning hedging. I give a perfect example of why hedging is a valuable trading tool and a perfect time to use it. I don't like what the markets do at holiday times, so I can hedge my trades and come back after to trade again without taking unnecessary risks. Now I have to take some risks to protect my account. Stupid NFA.  
  
Because I could not hedge my positions just before Christmas I lost my 1300 pips profit I had and my losses continued. I would rather have hedged all my positions and come back after the new year and kept my 1300 pip profit for December. I never would have gotten so deep in the hole if I could have done that. So I dont want any idiots coming on my thread talking about how they cant see how hedging is a benefit for the trader and the NFA is trying to protect traders from themselves. My position is the NFA is trying to force traders into a certain trading style of trading not protecting me from brokers. Banning hedging is a benefit to brokers because now certain trading styles, like mine, have to take deep losses instead of hedging until we get more favorable trading scenarios. Sorry to rant and rave.

Thank you Mr. Toothman. Here is another change and makes a great read. Change the BB bands to:  
1\. 50 post the main line with Dev set at 2 shift 1.  
2\. 51 Dev. 3 shift 1 use dotted lines   
3\. 49 Dev. 1 shift 1 use dotted lines  
4\. RSI to 8 with lines at 75 and 25  
  
New entrance points for recovery BB bands Dev. 3  
Measure distance from Dev. line 3 to Dev. line 2 = total pips A  
Measure distance from 1st entrance to Dev. line 3 = total pips B  
tpA = recovery distance  
tpB = amount needed to recover  
Division is tpB / tpA  
  
What is multiplication to break even?  
If distance for tpB 210 pips in the hole  
If distance for tpB is 70 pips  
210/70 = 3   
Multiply next level entrance by 3, set your TP for both levels to break even.  
You are out. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)   
So you want out of a bad trade or you want a quick TP off of level 3 BB There are your numbers. When price hits Dev. level 3 enter and then TP at level 2. Confirm RSI above below 25/75. An RSI warning system probably exists somewhere at FF. An EA that enters off of Dev. 3 would be easy to write. What do you think???  
See pic below. I also attached the template. HMMMMMMMM will study this one. May lead to new entrance rules. Scalping the 4H chart. yuk yuk

The other thing I forgot to mention is when you see price bouncing between Dev. 2 and 1 you know you are in trouble. If you want to take a minumum loss Dev. 1 is your recovery TP for a minimum loss on the 2.4.2 recovery system. This looks good, I like the clear cut rules here. If you are in a trade and you want to break even reenter outside Dev. 2 or 3 TP at next deviation line and do the math. I love it when pieces come to gether. Again if you use Dev. 2 you confirm with the RSI being >< 25/75.  
  
Another thought if you are 3 levels deep do the math for just one level. So you want level 3 to break even your level 1 trade and you leave level 2 to see if price breaks in your favor. If it doesnt then you will use a L4 trade to break even your level 2 but you have already closed out 1 and 3 so they would be your present level 1 and 2. I know clear as mud. In other words, if you are at 3 levels you dont need to try to clear both level 1 and 2 at the same time if your margin is tight or you dont want to risk a high multiplication.

Some currencies have not ended their Christmas trends yet so be careful AUD/JPY is one of them. It looks tempting but I dont know how to read a 3+ week of constant trending without a major retrace. If it continues it will be week 4 and it is possible with the an expectation of some USA selloffs and the money going into the AUD and NZD pairs. Higher interest rate.   
_**TAKE PROFITS  
**_  
_**CLOSED FOR LOSS**_  
  
_**OPEN TRADES  
**_  
  
_**TOTALS**_  
total for day 0  
for the week 0  
for the month 0  
Carry over 0  
  
_**primary trades**_  
**_BUYS_**   
_**SELLS**_ Aud/Nzd,  
  
_**Secondary trades  
**__**BUYS**_ Eur/Aud, Gbp/Chf _**  
SELLS**_ Aud/Cad,   
  
OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:  
This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,   
4 of each eur, usd, jpy  
  
_**aud/cad - aud/nzd**_ this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.  
_**  
chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd**_  
  
_**gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy**_  
  
_**Alternatives:**_ the _**a****ud/jpy, eur/jpy,**_ are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the _**EUR/NZD**_ is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with _**nzd/chf or nzd/jpy**_. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.   
  
_**Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.**_  
I no longer trade _**usd/sgd.**_ It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

_**TAKE PROFITS  
**_Aud/Nzd, +6 I will look for a reentrance on this one. Put a sell at just below resistance and just below support.   
_**CLOSED FOR LOSS**_  
  
_**OPEN TRADES  
**_Aud/Cad, -57  
Eur/Aud, +21 set SL to 0  
Gbp/Chf -45  
_**TOTALS**_  
total for day +6  
for the week 0  
for the month 0  
Carry over 0  
  
_**primary trades**_  
**_BUYS_** usd/chf  
_**SELLS**_ aud/usd nzd/usd  
  
_**Secondary trades  
**__**BUYS**_ _**  
SELLS**_   
  
OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:  
This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,   
4 of each eur, usd, jpy  
  
_**aud/cad - aud/nzd**_ this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.  
_**  
chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd**_  
  
_**gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy**_  
  
_**Alternatives:**_ the _**a****ud/jpy, eur/jpy,**_ are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the _**EUR/NZD**_ is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with _**nzd/chf or nzd/jpy**_. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.   
  
_**Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.**_  
I no longer trade _**usd/sgd.**_ It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

My definition of a secondary trade is a trade that was previously a primary trade but has now double or tripled top or is showing divergance on a 4H chart (they are going into a head and shoulders pattern). To me they are just as good as a primary in fact they are usually better in that the move is usually bigger than the original primary trade. What I am going to do now is add to the system with straddle trades. I have taken my profit but just in case the trade continues to run I will stay in it or if it goes back to its previous entrance signal I will try to enter at its extreme. So we see how it goes.   
  
One thing I am working on is an EA that will automatically move the SL up to 0 and then +10 on straddle trades and also will only trade once and quit. Once I get that EA written and working properly I want to start following the trend more with straddle trades using 4H and 1D S/R lines. Hopefully it will add to our profits. No it is part of the method, we multi level trade because there is no 100% certainty price will change at the signals. What you want to do now is ride your second level and try to break even or get a small profit on this trade. When the trade is equalized put in SL so you dont lose the break even or minimal loss and then see if the trade continues into profit. The difference between my system and others is, instead of taking SL we try to break even on losing trades so our equity curve will keep moving up over time. It takes time to grasp this concept in trading when you have been hammered with USE A STOP LOSS all your trading life. My philosophy is only take a SL in extreme cases and always try to break even. December was the only time I took an extreme loss but that was a very rare exception in price movement. Prices moved for 3-4 weeks without retracing which is something I had not seen before. So it was good I had quit trading in December. So that is the basic philosophy behind this system. Also I usually do not reenter on less than 150 pips but we are so high up on the screen I went ahead and did at the R line. If you reenter too early it can also cause problems.

an update:  
  
**Goodbye US Forex industry: Part 2**  

  2. 0 Comments

Continuing my post from last Friday about the CFTC’s anti-Forex regulations (I dear you to fathom this [193 pages document](http://www.cftc.gov/ucm/groups/public/@newsroom/documents/file/forexrulesproposal.pdf)) there are couple more points we should discuss:  
1\. First one is the “Foreign Exchange Dealers Coalition” manifest first [published](http://blogs.fxstreet.com/francesc/2010/01/15/forex-dealers-coalition-says-us-1billion-forex-industry-in-danger/) by fxstreet’s Francesc. It’s an interesting piece of paper, not solely because of its content, but also by the first ever appearance of a US retail forex brokers’ alliance – and this is a revolution, no less. It seems that in fear of the worst even forex brokers can unite. This is highly important because brokers unity is perhaps US industry’s last chance and because for the first time the brokers collectively realized the danger. This however is probably too late.  
CFTC is all but done introducing the new requirements, and this Comment Period is just a bureaucratic procedure. US brokers should realize that the window to fend off this attack is long gone, and it’s time to adapt to a whole new reality – the US government doesn’t want you there, it prefers you to move to offshore locations. Unfortunately for you, these offshore locations are already pretty well inhabited by other brokers so the rules of game are much more different now.  
The Foreign Exchange Dealers Coalition summarizes their stand with the following:  
“The case against the 10 to 1 leverage rule is clear. The rule will be a boon to foreign forex dealers (both regulated and unregulated) who will grow entirely at the expense of retail forex dealers in the United States. Thousands of high paying jobs will be lost and the potential for tens of thousands of more jobs will forever vanish as well. Consumers will be hurt and more vulnerable to fraud. And the United States will toss away one of the most promising export industries that it has, all in the midst of 10% unemployment. There is no good reason that this should be so.”  
_They are spot on, but nobody in the CFTC cares._  
2\. The second point that most is overlooked while focusing on the 10-to-1 leverage requirement (which is crucial by itself) is that CFTC ‘proposed’ not only the reduction in leverage but also 193 pages of other requirements. In fact, it’s a whole new book of how the retail forex industry should look like. For instance:  
Subject to certain exceptions (e.g., for certain regulated financial intermediaries not under the Commission’s jurisdiction as established in the CRA), the Proposal would require persons offering to be or acting as counterparties to retail forex transactions but not primarily or substantially engaged in the exchange traded futures business, to register as retail foreign exchange dealers (“RFEDs”) with the CFTC. Registered futures commission merchants (“FCMs”) that are “primarily or substantially” (as defined in the Proposal) engaged in the activities set forth in the Act’s definition of an FCM would be permitted to engage in retail forex transactions without also registering as RFEDs.  
**Do they mean SEC registered retail forex brokers (there are a few which are not primarily futures brokers summerstreetfx.com for instance)?**  
The Proposal would further require certain entities other than RFEDs and FCMs that intermediate retail forex transactions to register with the Commission as introducing brokers (“IBs”), commodity trading advisors (“CTAs”), commodity pool operators (“CPOs”), or associated persons (“APs”) of such entities, as appropriate, and to be subject to the Act and regulations applicable to that registrant category. In addition, the Proposal would require any IB that introduces retail forex transactions to an RFED or FCM to be guaranteed by that RFED or FCM.  
**Ouch.**  
The Proposal would also implement the $20 million minimum net capital standard established in the CRA for registering as an RFED or offering retail forex transactions as an FCM; propose an additional volume-based minimum capital threshold calculated on the amount an FCM or RFED owes as counterparty to retail forex transactions.  
**So where do US brokers go from here? Offshore.**

Here is a letter I sent to my Senators from Florida. You may want to send letters to your Senators. Time to get involved guys, but probably too late.  
  
Senator Bill Nelson   
Washington, D.C.  
United States Senate  
716 Senate Hart Office Building  
Washington, DC 20510  
  
Senator George LeMieux  
United States Senate  
356 Russell Senate Office Building  
Washington, DC 20510  
  
Dear Senator,   
  
I have been a Forex trader for 3 years now. Even though my winnings have been modest I have enjoyed being a trader. However, due to new regulations Forex dealers and small time traders like myself are being forced out of the market. Please read the following and understand I am tired of govt. regulators joining forces with big time companies and wiping out the little guy. Please read the following story and let me know if there is anything that can be done. Otherwise I have to do my trading overseas in England or Australia where they dont punish the little guy. Why export more business and jobs when we need them here in the USA. I consider these men dangerous to this industry and they only want a small group of traders and companies to enjoy trading.   
  
  
Goodbye US Forex industry  
  
* Posted by Michael Greenberg in Brokers, Traders  
  
So what do you when someone is constantly bullying and harassing you at your neighbourhood? Do you call the police, try to take a stand yourself or just run? Well, sometimes when nothing else helps and the situation is escalating, and this has been going on for ages it’s better just to find a new home. You tried your best and it’s not surrendering rather it’s an understanding that if someone powerful doesn’t want you there you can find better places where you can have your old quality of life back.  
  
And my US Forex trading friends, the CFTC doesn’t want you there.  
  
It doesn’t want you trading Forex with the US brokers who will gradually shift their operations to offshore locations where the regulator doesn’t have a conflict of interest or a powerful futures lobby forcing it to make all the wrong decisions.  
  
Latest from CFTC is that it is “seeking public comment” on proposed leverage reduction to 10-to-1. We all know what this means: the rule is all but finalized and they just let you feel as if you are important to their decision making process. Whether you are a large broker or a small time retail trader, this will probably make no difference to these guys with a very clear agenda.  
  
Now, I’m sure i’ll surprise you here but I’m actually a fan of a lower leverage. HOWEVER, I don’t think it should be forced on ALL forex traders. High leverage is a number one reason that newbie forex traders lose all their money. However, many professional traders as well as money managers, hedge funds, etc use high leverage in order to achieve better returns or just because their strategies require that. Some also use high leverage in order to cheaply hedge their exposure in other forex transactions.  
  
  
(These are my comments not the authors. I disagree with the author on this point. High leverage is the best way to learn this industry. WHY? Because I risk less money to learn. For example, If I use 500 dollars at 400:1 leverage. My maximum loss would be 500 dollars. I will need to risk 2000 dollars to trade the same way at 100:1. My maximum loss would be 2000 dollars. With the new laws I will need to risk 20,000 at 10:1. When you are learning to be a trader which is better for you. Risk 500 dollars or 20K. This is obvious. Leverage is not my enemy it is my friend and the friend of every new trader. It allows us to lose small sums of money in the hopes of one day learning to trade larger sums. I would never have wanted to learn to trade FOREX if my minimum investment was 20K dollars. However, learning at 500 dollars was worth the price of training. The men who are writing the regulations are not protecting the small time investor they are killing them so that only a few big boys can trade. This is not an American concept. I want the freedom to trade, to learn, to lose or gain money in a free and open market. These regulators are not protecting the small investor they are wiping them out so only a privileged few can trade. Please protect my freedom to trade as I wish. I wish to trade with USA brokers but if govt. regulators wipe them out then I will be forced to use a foreign broker.)  
  
Limiting leverage to novice traders is a great thing. Limiting leverage to ALL traders is horrible. I would recommend the CFTC to differentiate in their requirements and instead of imposing rules on all traders as if they were all identical set some kind of proficiency/experience test which will determine whether the trader can you use the leverage of his choice or be subject to a low leverage. Such test can be that trader’s testament to years of experience in trading or something of this nature.  
  
I’ll send them this note, but I doubt it’ll make any difference. If anyone else would like to comment on that they are welcomed to send a note to: [secretary@cftc.gov](mailto:secretary@cftc.gov) with “Regulation of Retail Forex” as the subject line. People, be nice or they will just throw your emails to garbage and ignore all other more balanced emails.  
  
CFTC also oversees the vast Futures industry where many high leveraged products are present. Some are as leveraged as the spot forex right now. So why are these products aren’t limited to 10-to-1 leverage ratio? Why is it only the spot forex that is dealt with regulatory blows over and over again?  
  
CFTC should have long time ago required all brokers to switch to ECN trading model and reduce leverage to novice traders. That’s it. That would have been so much better to the whole US forex industry, but I guess CFTC has it’s own considerations here…  
  
Unfortunately as far as I know other regulators like FSA (UK) and FINMA (Switzerland) may take a similar approach as they look to work closely with the CFTC/NFA. Let’s hope they don’t but time will tell.  
  
So my US forex friends, I suggest you don’t wait 60 days till the comment period is over or till the requirements are imposed – and they will be imposed as-is, find yourself a nice cosy offshore home and forget about all the problems you had at your old place.  
  
Sincerely,  
  
Robert Villmow

Next time have a plan for your exit. I just am going to use your exit as an example. If you use the S/R indicator on a daily chart you will see that priced stopped right at a major S/R line on the daily. The plan should have been, if price breaks this S/R line on the daily then exit. If it bounces off look for my best exit for the trade. I would have put a sell here to minimize my lose if it bounced and exit some point above if price kept going. You will learn in trading to minimize losses playing off of these major S/R lines. Notice the Daily chart below. You can see the blue line I drew showing two major S/R spots in the past. I put white arrow pointing to them. If price breaks that point your plan would be to exit. If price bounces your plan is to take the sell and reduce my loss. Once you get the hang of using S/R lines you can increase your profits and decrease your losses more. I hope this is a help to you. Next time plan where you want to take your loss, dont do it at the R line, do it after it is clearly broken. Look for the bounce and see if you get it, many times you will get it.

USD/JPY. Do I ride the trade or TP. That is always the question when you come to a S/R line. Blue and White are at the top but good news last night for the USA so it could continue. What do you do? I have been straddle trading these trades. I take my maximum profit at the R line and then put a pending order buy on the other side. I also put a pending order buy at its previous S line in case we have a double bottom. So here is a pic of my trade and set up. I get tired of losing these small 20-50 pip profits because I think price will continue but they dont. So now I take them and use the pending order to follow the trade in case price does continue. There are several things about FOREX, theories I have developed about why price moves back and forth.  
1\. FOREX is NOT about traders. It was set up so businesses could trade world wide and banks are needed to exchange currencies. Most of the action comes from business and government transactions. As trade flows in one direction, sooner or later it has to also flow back.  
2\. When banks do transactions I believe the do all the buys first then the sells or visa versa. So price will move one way and then reverse. This is the cause of Monday gaps as banks process their weekend deposits and exchanges.  
3\. No matter what the fundamentals are if there has been a run on a currency and the banks have been selling say lots of CHF because businesses are exchanging GBP, sooner or later they need more CHF to sell their customers. So they have to buy some CHF to restock their supplies. Remember we trade in hundredths or thousandths of a penny, they exhange to the nearest penny, they make a whole lot more than we do on an exchange. So a move of 5-800 pips may not even be one penny at a bank counter but they need more CHF to make transactions with their customers so price retraces at some point.   
  
_**These are some of my theories**_ concerning FOREX and why I play the retraces. I know they are coming. S/R points are places where banks need to restock so price pauses, retraces and then continues if demand is still there. These retraces cause me to make profit or close out a trade for a minimum or zero loss. I know they have to come, banks need to balance their currency reserves. I dont know if I am right or wrong on this issue but it made sense to me on why price moves like it does. Banks needs in relation to business and government transactions is what moves the market on a daily basis.

Thanks for all your input but I would like to point out, no matter what MA cross you use, you will always get a peeker trade. In other words price will cross and then uncross. The larger the numbers you use the longer it takes for price to enter and then a lot of the move could be gone. I have tried many different combos. However, doing these things will be an immense help in learning price movement and reaction and you will learn a lot by doing these things. It could be possible you may get fewer DD but you may also find out the profitable trades arent as profitable. The number of pips wont be as big. So when ever you gain in one area you will be giving something up in another.  
  
I am working on an EA that will move the stop loss to 0 and then +10 after x amount of pips and also trades only one time and then quits. So far cant get all the pieces working and the guy working on it cant do it now. So it wont stop all the peekers but the more we eliminate the better off we will be. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) Good luck.

I know what you mean by the peeker trades. Crosses and recrosses occur often inside a 4HR candle. Right now I'm manually testing this 5,8 cross at the close of the candle with just a 50 TP. This after red line is at extreme and price is in upper or lower 1/3 of chart. You'll still get peeker trades at candle close but far less of them. So far what I've seen is you can almost always take 50 pips with a L1(TP set for 50) or L2 (TP set for around 100) and the 5,8 gives much better entry points when a pair goes on a long run without a retrace. That said, I still like the idea your working on and hope your programer can help you soon. I'll be looking at a 5,8 cross with that idea also.

In my downloads I have the same size lot philosophy but I have been using a progressive reentrance that works like this. If I originally played L1 5, L2 5, L3 5 that equals 15. Now I can play 3, 5, 8 which equals 16. This gives me smaller DD and quicker recovery. I dont need as many pips to 0 out a position but the total amount does not change. I am finding this slightly less profitable but much easier to erase a DD. The maximum amount of positions I am in in any trade is 3. After testing various martingale philosophies, 3 positions max seemed to give me the best return of risk to reward ratio. My win percentage is over 70% and I hit my SL of around + - 400 maybe 1-3 times a month on an average. I usually will win 1500-2500 pips a month so my monthly total always looks good. December was my one losing month but that was an extreme move I had not see before and dont expect to see that type of move again. In other words that was a very rare move of the forex to trend for 3 or more weeks without a major retracement on so many pairs at one time. Good luck trading.

Sorry I missed your question. This EA is run on Tick value. Here is the line in the code:  
  
PipValue=MarketInfo(Symbol(),MODE_TICKVALUE);   
I dont know how you would change this but I looked at the different mode values and if you changed this to MODE_OPEN I think this would change it to the next bar open. You test that on a demo and find out.   
In other EAs you have to turn the Tick value to off and then it reads by bars. For example in another EA it has this function:  
extern bool EachTickMode = True;  
You would then put it to false and then the EA would operate according to the bars on the chart you are using.   
  
My suggestion would be is to have a regular MA cross EA that does not reenter (mult-level or martingale EA) You could change the Magic number and use multiple EAs to have the multi-level effect. For example EA #1 would be .01 magic number 1; EA #2 would be .02 and magic number 2 and so on. If price enters on the first EA and then uncrosses you could then put the 2nd EA on and then it would enter a 2nd level at the new cross. A multilevel approach using MA crosses but using regular EAs. Since you would have several magic numbers at once you would need a third EA that would close all trades when PT is reached or set the PT manually or have each EA have its on PT. I will probably go to this idea when I get my new EA ready for my 4H system. It allows me to reenter off of price movement instead of a fixed number and then you could set a profit target.  
  
Here is a universal MA cross EA I have used from time to time.

Scenario #1:   
If MA1 OPEN is > MA5 & MA8 Buy  
OR  
Scenario #2:  
If MA1 OPEN is > MA5 & MA5 > MA8 BUY

I am excited, I have what I have been looking for in a trade manager program:  
Go to this website for explanations on how it works:  
<http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=89371>  
  
In a nutshell this program will manage all or part of your trades according to what inputs you want. Some but not all of the things it does is:  
_**Multi-purpose trade manager**_ – instructions for use  
This ea supervises open trades and offers these facilities for:   
● selected individual trades;  
● groups of trades linked by a common magic number or comment;   
● or all trades  
● Moves the stop loss at appropriate intervals – to breakeven, jumping stop, trailing stop.   
● Offers the option to hide the stop from the broker; likewise the take profit.  
● Close all open trades when the upl reaches a set target; this can include pending orders.  
● Part-closure (50%) when the price reaches a set target.  
● Hedge-trade opening for trades that are going bad.  
● Equity protection: close all open trades when upl hits a specified level.  
By default, all options are set to 'false', so the ea will do nothing until you choose some  
  
In other words I can set this EA to my EAs magic number or all my trades and it will automatically move my SL up to 0 after x amount of pips, then +10 after x amount of pips and then every 50 pips (or any chosen number) it will move 50 pips. You can have it do a MT4 trailing stop or a jump stop where it doesnt move until price moves 50 pips (or any other number) Anyway read the material, test it on a demo and let me know how it works I will be trying it out. I have had several trades, (in fact, most of my deep DD trades started quickly in profit 20-50 pips) then reversed. This program would catch the minimum profit of +10 or breakeven and then we could reenter at the next cross. This will also need an EA that trades once and quit and we have one of those. In other words if the Hopwood EA closes a trade you dont need the EA reentering on you again at that point. So test it out and let me know.

Thanks Bob. This addition should add some protection against those long runners that don't want to reverse. Take the small profit and wait for the stronger reversal later. Just to add my two cents, I've been looking at another way to decide when to add a L2 or L3 to a trade that goes against you. As I described in earlier posts, I like to trade this system manually with a TP set at 50. I'm entering when I'm seeing first that red, white and blue are at extremes. Price is at top or bottom 1/3 of chart and RSI(8) shows divergence. My idea of when to enter another level is wait until divergence happens a second time instead of just jumping in at a fixed 150-200 pips step. This may help keep DD smaller by trying to reenter at a spot that is more likely to see some reversal. The chart below shows an example. I waited until close of red candles to confirm divergence. First level trade was a no go but second level trade was a winner.

I am adding this to my chart but RSI 8 divergence looks good to me. I was taught on MACD divergence but you rarely see that on a 4H chart. RSI divergence looks like a winner though. Here is a pic. Notice A1 higher highs on price action but lower highs on RSI. B1 Double bottom on chart but higher lows on RSI. Looks good Toothman, great idea. Entrance then can be anyplace above or equal to A1 or Lower than or equal too B1. Try to enter as close to the highs or lows you can get. Not a bad idea. Or a pending order at the break in the S/R level at this point.

Here is a pic of the eur/jpy trade that was so much trouble. After watching these kind of trends, I have come up with a way to handle them and will publish my ver 3 hopefully this weekend. I found a way to pick up the trade at all the orange arrows and you are going to love it. Demo the EAs etc now making sure everything works. Anyway a trend trader will be jumping up and down saying follow the trend, follow the trend. The problem is when did the trend start? How long will it last? and when and where should you get out or get in? In my pic I made a critical decision that the trend would continue once it passed the 50MA (white arrow). Well it didnt and I ended up with a big DD. I could have exited my trades there (eur/jpy, chf/jpy, nzd/jpy) for small losses. Instead I stayed in (followed the new trend ??) and got into trouble. I am again at this decision point and this time I closed out the trade. A trend trader has to decide to continue following the trend, but which way? Follow it up if it breaks the 50MA or play the bounce and follow the trend?? Tomorrow all over the world so called trend trader gurus will say didnt I tell you to follow the trend, see how it broke the 50MA and continued. See the H&S on the bottom and how it broke the previous swing high. You need to get in. _**OR**_ See how price bounced of off the 50 MA and continued on the trend. Sell the rallies, how many times do I have to say sell the rallies. So what is it trend traders? answer me this? Is this a sell the rally for the DT will continue or buy the new trend, it broke the previous highs and has the candle and chart pattern buy, buy, buy or Get the picture. (see the aqua arrow) tomorrow they will have the answer. I want the answer today. My viewpoint is I stay out of the middle of the charts, dont know what will happen there. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Here is a pic of what the new Ver. 3 will look like. I have a new indicator which is the red line high and red line low. The EA only enters when price breaks that line, so I think we have made a superior entrance point. Even if price goes against you for a while it wont for long. Had some real nice profits on the demo tests. Also added Hopwoods trade manager program. It will bring your SL to break even and then that eliminates suprise DD and peeker trades that sometimes happened with 3x3 cross, actually all MA crosses have this problem. So here are the rules.  
1\. New indicator #1 divides the screen into fourths (bold gold lines). We trade in the top and bottom 25%. Sell EA used only above this line. Buy EA used below this line. The EA only enters when price goes above this line by 1 pip. Gets you really a really good entrance I think. Shouldnt be much DD.   
2\. R,W,B lines near the top or bottom of the screen, also taking secondary trades.  
3\. RSI is above the 30 or below 70. Rule 3B. May always take trades above 90 or 10 RSI. I changed the 8 RSI to a 5. The position of the RSI doesnt change but the lines are more definitive. I have the old RSI 8 in dotted lines for comparison.   
4\. Rule 4 is when we see divergance on the RSI, you can take half profit and go for the run up/down in price. You will put a 45 degree angle line on the RSI and stay in the trade until the RSI crosses that line. This is seen on trades 2 and 4. If you did this with the others it would not work as well.   
5\. Sell the Rallies, buy the dips. Trade 5 is a rally that came back to the gold line and we take that trade. Not sure how to explain it but we can call it a tertiary trade. Price pulls back up to an old S line so we take it if the EA will.   
  
SO here are the trade scenarios.   
1\. secondary trade  
2\. Primary trade also divergance. Draw 45 degree line on RSI and go for the big pip move. Take half profit and let it ride till you cross the 45 degree line on RSI.  
3\. Same as #1  
4\. Same as #2, this time the RSI ride is a very good one. We actually stay in this trade for 3 days. We took half earlier and we are now riding the trade down.   
5\. Tertiary trade price bounces back up to an old S line so we take it as it nears the gold line and Old S line. If price doesnt break that red line we are not in. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) If we get in and price goes against up we are at the top of the chart.   
6\. With a break in the 45 degree line and divergance on RSi we now go to a buy. This trade probably hit our break even for no pips.   
7\. Primary trade- off of divergance and probably trade 6 didnt get us much so 7 is another entrance.   
After trade 7 there may be some secondary trades.  
  
That is what I am trying to put together but I need to fine tune it and make sure everything is working. Will try to post it Tues or Wed. unless I come across another problem. Enjoy the pic.

It shouldnt make any difference because you will see the divergance and have the EA on. When it enters the trade you will monitor it. I have seen pics with RSI in which you will get 3 or 4 divergances before you get the real change of direction. In this system 5 things will happen:  
1: The MPTM will bring your SL to breakeven, price reverses on you and you have a zero trade.   
2\. Price will move to the TP of the EA and close out that trade then the EA waits for the next entrance point.  
3\. You are using the jump SL which I will start at 25. So at +25 you are at 0 50 it moves the SL to +25, 75 it moves to +50 and so on until price reverses and you have profit.   
4\. Price never gets to the +20 so you have a negative trade in which we start looking for a second entrance and we multi-level trade like we did in the past.  
5\. Price went in your favor, on divergance we play the long run so we profit 1/2 at some point and then close out the other half when RSI crosses a 45% angle which we will draw on the chart. So whether divergance is at the open or close does not matter. We only want to see it.

I am not sure quite what you are saying. Before we discuss we need to define divergence. Divergence is when the lowest lows of the candles which you have drawn a line on the chart forming a line pointing downward. Then you connect the lowest lows on the RSI which you have drawn on the chart but that line is angling upward over the same time period. That would be divergence. The lines are going in opposite directions. With that definition you have drawn divergence in your picture. When I talk about divergence that is what I mean. I guess there are other definitions but I assume that is the most common one.  
  
In counter trend trading we are not necessarily looking for a complete price reversal as we are just a retracement. If price has dropped 200 pips or more and now is retracing we get that trade. The divergence may not necessarily point out a true price reversal as it would a correction. This may sound crazy to people who have been trend trading but I find trading retracements easier to trade than a trend. If you are a channel trader to me it is easier to go from the outside of the channel in than inside out. If I am on the very outside it is extremely rare for price to go even more higher without retracing first. If I am on the inside of the channel hoping it will continue going up I feel I am in a guessing crapshoot. Maybe it will, probably it wont or it will fake or ....... But outside in I feel I have a much better chance, I know price will go back to a median but once it gets back I dont know if it will go up or down.

Hi Bob  
  
I think your problem is with sell orders in mptm. I have just checked the mptm and I was getting the same problem as you (i.e. closing and part closing at the same time). I went back and read the instructions once again and it clearly states:  
  
"BreakEvenProfit: will add this to the stop loss to a buy order, subtract it for a sell order. My default of 2 pips means the sl is set to break even + 2, ensuring a minimum of 2 pips profit. Set it to 0 if you do not want this feature."  
  
For short orders Breakeven profit should be a minus value. I looked at the problem orders and they were all SHORTS. So I just changed the Breakeven profit to 0 and all working OK now. For ease of understanding and clarity I am atatching a picture of this section of the settings which is now working OK.

A little studie about the 25% lines:  
  
In _chart 1_ we have the two horizontal lines drawn with the "NB Fourths" indicator.  
  
_Just a technical remark: the autor use the internal functions "WindowPriceMax(0)" and "WindowPriceMin(0)". This functions returns the upper and lower border values from the visible window, and not the HigherHigh and LowerLow prices!_  
  
_Chart 2_ has the same number of bars like chart1 (120 bars = ca. 1 month).  
I programmed a little HighLow indicator to calculate the 25% lines. The indicator takes everytime the last 120 bars to calculate this lines.  
(A nice option is to make the calculation with Open and Close, not only with High and Low).  
  
If we compare the signals, we see that in chart1 on the left edge we have signals only in chart 2.  
  
Now if we scroll the first chart, we see in _chart 3_ that at the moment who we have the days from 22.Jan on the right edge, the signals appear also in chart1.  
  
Conclusion: if also the MACD were programmed to draw scaled values for the last 120 bars, than we can analyse correct the signals back!  
The current versions for drawing the 25% lines and the MACD are valid only at the right edge of the charts.  
.

Hi,  
A single instance of the MPTM EA can handle any of these scenarios:  
  
J _ust the pair the EA is currently running on  
All trades anywhere on the account  
A selection of trades based on the magic number of the EA which created them  
__A selection of trades based on the comment field_  
_A single trade based on the Ticket Number_  
  
The very latest addition which I have not yet tested adds another possibility being to manage a selection of trades based on the Symbol field (EURUSD, GBPJPY etc).  
  
Also you can combine any of the above which are logical, so for instance you could manage only the pair the EA is on & then only trades created by a specific EA, by using it's magic number.  
  
Hope this helps ...
