This discussion happened on my other forum and it applies to the gold lines on why and how they work. So I thought I would copy and paste it here.  
  
"I am a little confused here. Surely these new indicators draw lines that are based on the screen being viewed and ignore price. ie they simply split the screen up into equal segments So if I have a lesser no of bars on my screen than you do or if I magnify the display etc we will have different price entry points for trades etc Fibs and Pivots levels are based on calculations from price so will be the same no matter how the chart is displayed This would explain why you cannot back test it unless in visual mode ie Without a screen display how could the EA know what the levels were! I would have thought it better to base this new approach on price so everyone at least were singing from the same hymn sheet so to say  
  
I see Swingman in your other thread has done an indicator along these lines Maybe we could use this as a basis Do you think this is in line with your new approach?  
  
Best Regards"  
  
You could but I use a 4H chart for almost all my trading. What you see on the screen is a 1 month period of price action therefore as price moves across the screen the movement of the gold lines are very slight over a period of a week. In reality they are just another form of moving average lines. If you change from a 4H chart to a 1H chart all indicators, all moving averages will change or move. You change the amount of time or information used for the calculations. These gold lines are a moving average of 1 month of price action but in instead of using candles it is the distance from the top to the bottom or the range calculated by MT4 for that pair. This figure is based on MT4 figures of how much price has moved for a particular currency pair. MT4 uses this figure to give you your screen size. So the distance from top to bottom is a price range calculation. The gold lines are a moving average of that range. I am a range trader, to me this is perfect for my range trading systems. I hope you understood this, they are really another form of a moving average line. All indicators are, it is just the math is different.

A discussion on the other thread is helping me to define what the gold lines are. Here is some more information. Hope you enjoy.   
  
When ever you change screen size you change levels. For example when you change from a 4H chart to a 1H chart, what are you really doing??? You are changing your screen size. 1H to 15M same thing. That changes all your indicators. It is the same thing. All these systems we have previously have one weakness and your chart shows this, You can get a sell while price is at the bottom of the screen and then as it goes north you are into the trade too early. These new lines can solve that problem. The lines are now fixed to the actual range of the particular currency instead of a set of numbers. When MT4 gives you a screen it is based on the range of the currency during that period of time. We are using that qualification as our foundation for trading. In other words MT4 has already done the work of the range of each currency. We use that math to determine the lines to trade from. Now that doesnt mean it does not create new weaknesses but we wont find out the new weaknesses until we get something consistent to test. What is hard to comprehend is your screen size is an indicator based on price action. That is why every currency has a different pip size for its screen. The usd/jpy from top to bottom is different from the gbp/jpy. WHY?? because the screen height is based on price action of the pair for the time period you are looking at. This maybe hard to fathom but your screen size is an indicator. [http://cdn.forexfactory.com/images/s.../yim/happy.gif](http://cdn.forexfactory.com/images/smilies/yim/happy.gif)

OK these are version EAs 3.1 I have changed some of them. 01 and 02 series are for non ECN and 03 and 04 are for ECN dealers. Also corrected a couple of more mistakes made in the code. This also solves my closing at the wrong time when I enter a 2nd level. When you use the 02 or 04 series for the 2nd level you have removed the 01, 03 series EA from your screen and the TP at the green line is no longer active. If you have a non ECN account the 03 and 04 series EAs will still work. If you have an ECN account the 01 and 02 series EAs _**should not**_ work.   
  
·The **101 and the 201** (except pink EAs) enter from the white outside lines and take profit at the green line.  
·The **102 and the 202** (except pink EAs) enter from the white outside lines and have no take profit at the green line.   
·** _101,102,201,202_** all have take profit and stop loss settings placed at the time of the trade.   
·** _103,203,104,204 are for ECN dealers. They have no stop loss or take profit settings._**  
·The **103 and 203** series have no SL or TP and are used with ECN MT4 dealers. They will close the trade at the green line.   
·The **104 and 204** series have no SL, TP or Green line profit. All they do is enter the trade, you manage the trade after that.   
·The numbers are also the magic number for each EA.  
·Any EAs with pink in its name enters on the cross of the pink line instead of the white line.  
dont forget to save the new EAs to your template or you will get the old setup.

Oh I forgot the idea is when the conditions are right for entry instead of immediate entry or using the EA, to put a PENDING order of say 25 pips difference (e.g. if the system indicates a long entry at price of 0.1500, a pending order for 0.1525 is placed). I am sorry if I did not explain properly. The whole point is to reduce DD and hence Margin. This is only for the initial entry only. Once position is open everything is done according to the system. Pending order MAY (with a big emphasis on MAY) help to reduce DD. For instance when the conditions are right for a long entry instead of instant execution we place a pending order 25 pips above the present price if after 8 hours price has gone done by 50 pips we move the pending order 50 pips lower and so on. Once the retrace starts and the price starts going up our order is triggered.  
  
I hope I managed to get m point across.

IMHO a jumping stop gives better results than a trailing stop - both routines work fine.  
  
The MPTM handles each trade individually, including any hedge trades it opens. For instance in my manual trading I will often have 6 trades open, 3 buy & 3 sell and each is handled individually according to the rules set for that currency pair. The hedge trades are opened by the MPTM, at a set pip loss.  
  
Hope that helps ...

mptm does not open trades, it only manages the SL line. It brings the SL line ot break even after 20 pips and if you use the Jump MPTM it will move the SL line up every 25 pips. You only enter trades when you turn on the EA. The EA only enters when price crosses. If you use the 3x3 then a trade is entered at the cross. If you use the 100 or 200 series EAs the EA enters when price crosses the white or pink lines depending on which one you use. We tested version 3 here but when I finalized it I moved it on to a new thread because it bacame a trend following system. This thread will continue to be a countertrend system.

If price backs up on the second trade and takes the +5 yes it is good because then you wont have a second DD trade. When price recrosses and enters again then you are in a better trade position.   
  
One EA will reenter every 200 pips, if you use a second EA later with a different magic number then it will reenter at the cross. Since the EAs have different magic number the MPTM will handle them as separate trades not as one. If one closes the other does not. If it is the same ea when one trade closes so will the other.

I am not quite sure what you are asking? Your ticket when it enters gives you the entrance price and time. The high or low of a candle would give you the most extreme price so you can check to see if it went the x # of pips. The NB exposure or iexposure indicator gives you the entrance price and the sell/buy line on your screen gives you the entrance price with the spread included. In back testing there is an arrow on the screen giving price and entrance and you would have to manually check it against the high and low. However, backtesting will use higher and higher TF the farther back in time you go so the less accurate the entrance price would be. Back testors dont use the variable [spreads](/brokers/spreads "View Live Spreads on the Broker Guide") so they are not that accurate for what you what I think. Eye ball backtesting actually will give you the best results in this case if you want to stare at the screen all day.

My belief is that all EAs use indicators and all indicators do not predict news stories or strong fundamentals and need monitoring or human intervention. No matter what indicators we use sooner or later the market will move in a way that will defeat them. Having some knowledge of fundamentals is important to Forex trading. For example, If Greece files bankruptcy or the USA and China get into a pissing match over exchange rates, no indicator can predict the outcome or change of direction either when or how much. Indicators have limitations and if you understand those limitations they are valuable tools in trading. For example, if Greece goes bankrupt sell Euros no matter what the indicators are saying.

Hi Bob,  
  
You must delete the follwing passage in the 6x6-EA:  
  
  
if (PreviousOpenOrders>OpenOrders)   
{   
for(cnt=OrdersTotal()-1;cnt>=0;cnt--)  
{  
if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))  
{  
mode=OrderType();  
if ((OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber) || AllSymbolsProtect)   
{  
if (mode==OP_BUY || mode==OP_SELL)  
{   
OrderClose(OrderTicket(),OrderLots(),OrderClosePrice(),slippage,ArrowsColor);  
return(0);  
}  
}  
}  
}  
for(cnt=0;cnt<OrdersTotal();cnt++)  
{  
if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))  
{  
mode=OrderType();  
if ((OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber) || AllSymbolsProtect)   
{  
if (mode==OP_SELLLIMIT || mode==OP_BUYLIMIT || mode==OP_BUYSTOP || mode==OP_SELLSTOP)  
{  
OrderDelete(OrderTicket());  
return(0);  
}  
}  
}  
}  
  
  
This passage is responsible for the multiple close of all open trades with the same Symbol and MagicNumber!!  
If you delete that Closing-Part of the EA it will only open trades and do not close any trade.  
  
With the MPTM-EA you can use the "ManageByTicketNumber" instead of "ManageByMagicNumber".

DD seems to be something I cant avoid unless you use stop losses. Basically my stop loss is after it crosses 400 deep. I seldom have to use it maybe once or twice a month, I think I had one month with 3. The other side is I keep making these profits almost every day. THe problem is I dont know which currency will trend like crazy and usually every month one will. This time it is the JPY last time it was the GBP. Before that I think it was the EURO. If I could ever figure out which currency was going to do that every month it would be a perfect world for me. Despite all of that the DD prevents me from overextending myself with too large of lot size and now I dont wipe out accounts like I did years ago. So it has been a good lesson for me. Thanks for the compliment, I only publish what I have learned and I have never been able to keep my profits trend trading. To much whiplash and to many stop losses. I keep 3 buy EAs and 3 sell EAs with different Magic numbers. THis way the entrance is only made at the cross and not a predetermined pip number. When the MPTM closes a 2nd level trade, because it has a different Magic number it doesnt affect the other levels. When the 2nd level requalifies as a trade it will reenter the trade. So I pick up a half a dozen or so MTPM trades every day. Yesterday was a no mover day but I picked up 80 pips from it bouncing around the 2nd and 3rd level areas. It is working out very well. The MPTM works well with a MA cross system but does not seem to work well with a high/low system.

Too close maybe a problem, too far is not. I am testing a sixths EA with 5 lines on the screen so it adjusts to each currency. When price enters between two of the lines I make sure I dont get my second level unless it is in a different zone. So in the pic below of the aud/chf you can see level 1 (the white #1) and the second level (white #2). This is what I am using to keep my spacing with the different levels. So instead of a fixed number I am using what ever is the range of that currency. So I want trades to have the distance from one line to the next to be my spacing. In this trade my 3rd level would actually be a spot that is not even on the screen right now. I also am thinking of beyond top/bottom red line being my entrance area for volatile currencies and red to gold for others. I am also planning on writing a high/low and 6x6 cross EA. You only turn it on in the red area so you get your entrance at a high/low or if it doesnt it also enters at the cross. The red to gold area you only use the 6x6 cross. This will give you spacing designed for every currencies range rather than just 150 or 200. For example the gbp/nzd spacing is closer to 250 or 300 while the aud/chf spacing is around 100. So this will put everything together with simple rules for each area. If price is above red line use this EA #1 which will be a high/low or 6x6 (maybe the old 3x3) cross EA. if between the gold and red, use EA #2 which will be a 6x6 EA. When price goes against you the distance between two lines put on the 2nd Level EA for your 2ne entrance. Just some ideas I am working on. This will put all our latest ideas together into an easy to understand and usable system. Not so comlicated. See pic below:

Same indicator but I change the colors last night. You have the one with the previous colors. Same indicator though.   
MPTM is a separate EA from the 6x6. The MPTM manages all your trades and you put it on a separate screen all by itself. Go to Steve Hopwoods thread and he will explain all mechanics behind it.   
<http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=89371>  
  
In other words there is a thread dedicated to just explaining all of its functions. I just use the BE part with a TP of +10. So when the 6x6 enters a trade the MPTM will manage it. If price moves more than 20 pips it will set a TP of 10 as the SL. If it hits the SL of +10 it closes the trade. If the 6x6 is still crossed as a trade, it will then enter a new trade and start the process all over again. If you are in the same candle this is always true. The 6x6 will open another trade. If you are in a new candle and it retraces back to the +10 SL but it also uncrosses the 6x6 then it wont enter a new trade.

My philosophy is a little differetn. Even though no one desires DD my feelings are I can bring any DD back to zero if I am patient enough and chip away at it over time. If you have noticed I have already 0 out the eur/jpy and chf/jpy DD and now I will work on the aud/jpy and gbp/jpy DD. Instead of taking losses I use my profits and countertrades to eliminate them over a period of time. This is very hard to teach and to get others to understand but I am hoping over a period of time and by daily example you can see how I do that.   
  
My feelings on SL are you end up beating your head against the wall trying to make profit because I always seem to take enough SL to never get anywhere. My first two years of trading were like that. Make some money, lose it with SL and then going into the hole and then trying to catch back up to break even. Very frustrating. Got tired of that game. Maybe I am a little arrogant but I now believe I can take any DD and over time zero it out which means I will always keep my profits. It is a trading skill that takes time to develop. If you can make money using SL be my guest but I prefer to zero out my DD. So you can watch me do it with this latest DD.  
  
I do use manual SL but it is around 4-500 pips. I get 1-3 of those a month as an average. 1 so far this month.

The only thing I may work on this weekend is no more entrances after a certain amount of pips from the cross. For example if it takes the 100 pip profit I dont want it to reenter again. The reenters off of the MPTM dont bother me because I want to be in the trade. This is the philosophy: when the 6 crosses the 6 I want to be in the trade. If price bounces around a bit and hits a couple of MPTM TP that is ok with me. that is what I want. Sometimes price action is in the mud and this bouncing up and down is perfect for the MPTM. At least I capture something. If price goes against me than I wait for the next level entrance and away we go again. I dont mind the DD as much as other people. That is because I have had a lot of practice using the 2.4.2 recovery system and have gotten good at it. So no amount of DD bothers me. I also will add more money to my account if it passes the 20% mark. So if DD is more than 20% of my account I will add money to keep it out of trouble. This is working out real well for me.

Sorry I havent had a chance to answer all your comments. Love dealing with fellow educators, they seem to have the patience to learn the business and able to deal with its ups and downs. I guess much like teaching students in school. I have been in China almost 8 years now and the language is very difficult. My children picked it up but I have just a child's ability to speak it. Mainly my problem is I dont really need to use it here. I am one of the few foreigners here with an American wife (married 35 years this June) so I only speak English at home. I teach in a local Chinese Medical University so they only want me to speak English there. I have my school for foreign children so they only speak English there, I am the administrator but my wife is the boss (principal, she runs the place I just make sure we are legal and the bills are paid). I have learned enough to survive on the streets, buy things, take taxis, trips, and do some small talk. Chinese is a tonal language and it took three years for my ears to pick up the different tones. MA, MA , MA and MA are four different words in Chinese depending on the tone you use with the sound. So if you dont hear the tone you have no idea what they are saying and if you dont speak the correct tone they have no idea what you are saying. One tone MA means horse, another tone means mother, another tone means hemp ................. so I am sorry but I didnt mean I wanted to smoke your mother or No I didnt mean to call your mother a horse .......... and so on. Since I teach in a University they speak the common Mandarin taught in the schools but out on the streets they speak a form of Cantonese called Nanning Hua here. If you go to another town like BeiHai they will speak BeiHai Hua. So even though Cantonese is the language of the area in the cities, each city has its own version. Then when you get into the countryside you got all the dialects and each village will have its own versions of each dialect. There is Zhuang, Miao, Yao, etc. etc. One of the reasons China has not been a unified country in its past is it never really had a national language until Mao set up a standard Mandarin and then had all the schools teach the same language. He also unified the written language into a simpler form so it could be taught nationwide. We are now seeing the rise of a powerful country because of these improvements. Before this language prevented the Chinese from being a unified group of people and as their history books attest the foreigners took advantage of the situation. So China has never really been able to expand outside of its borders without a unified language. Well enough talk, back to trading. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

OK first it is working exactly the way it is suppose to work Price is entering and price retracing is causing you to get your +5. It did this 4 times. I use +10 and got it 2 times. Price then retraced and it is for now a negative trade. I got the same thing. Without the MPTM the EA would have entered and you would still be in a negative trade. You would have 0 pips in the bank and the broker still got his 5 pips for the spread. However, now you are in a negative trade but have 20 pips in the bank just like me. For me that happen 19 times yesterday and I put in the bank 190 pips. Without the MPTM I would not have had the 190 pips but much less. I only had 134 pips on non MPTM trades. Here is the only rule in trading that matters.**How much money did the broker cut you this month?** You cant have your broker cut you a check unless you have money going into the bank (closed trades). So go to your 4H chart and take a look at the aud/jpy for the week. It had two cross downs or two profitable trades if taken for the week. I was having trouble with my internet so I didnt get the first one but I did get the 2nd trade for 38 pips. That would have been my week without the MPTM. However, with it I also got 12 +10 for 120 pips making my week pocketed 158 pips just on one pair. With just the cross you enter make a profit and exit. With the MPTM you also pick up some pips with the bouncing around. Yes it reenters when it is in the same candle but if price is not going anywhere it may not reenter after that. The only thing that matters to me is what am I putting in the bank and the rest is how can I zero out this trade and go on. How much money the broker gets is irrelevant? He is in business for the same reason I am. I want him to make money so he stays in business and my money is safe. So for the 13 trades I made 138 pips. Aud/jpy spread is 5 pips so he made 65 pips. Compare that with I made 38 pips and he made 5 pips. I will gladly take the 138 and he can have his 65. We both win. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Here is another way of looking at it. I entered my first level trade back on March 22 with the aud/jpy. I am 3 weeks into this series of trades. Long time to hang in there. I have had 21 closed trades and 3 open trades. My DD at this point is 726 which is very high, dont have that happen often but it happens. 18 of my closed trades are MPTM; 15 are +10; 3 are +5 for 165 pips. I had two other profit trades of 61 and 50 for 111 and one losing trade closed at -14 for a total of 97 non mptm trades. 97 + 165 Total 262 pips in the bank. 726 DD - 262 (inthe bank) = 500. With 3 open trades on the board I need 166 pip retracement to break even pip wise, however with the larger lots as I reenter it is closer to 100 pips to break even. I will enter a 4th level Monday at the R line and wait for my retracement and be out at BE or if price bounces around keep picking up my MPTM until price does move. If price goes against me. I will drop my 1st level and try to BE on the rest. Lets say I drop my 1st level at -500. I already profited 262 so my loss on that trade will be 238 but I will be playing to make that up with fresh trades and will wipe that deficit out in 2 or 3 days. So my profit curb will take a dip and then continue upward. This is how my system works and if you can ever get it, (and I know it is difficult to grasp all of this, so if you dont get it, just keep plugging away until you do or go on to another system). But you must understand, in this series of trades, I may not make a profit but I am not going to take a loss either. I will have other trades that will profit and my losers I try to break even. Bottom line in the long run, I make money, my broker makes money, we are both happy.

Take the sample of previous transaction I posted, and assume the new 5th order is in DD and 50pips away from open price of first transaction ,e,g. current price is 87.43=86.93+50. If we don’t do MPTM, the loss is 50 pips.   
With this pips, we have 106 pips(87.43-86.37) unrealised P/L DD and 20 pips realised profit, the loss is 86 pips (106-20).   
  
Our bank account has two pockets, left pocket is realised P/L and right pocket unrealised which we are also responsible for.

Your broker is a 5 Digit broker so use the 5 digit EAs. When you trade during the day remember in day trading price usually follows the direction it is going. In other words once price goes north it will stay north for the day. If it is going south it will stay south for the day. Stay out of the middle of the chart and trade the edges. Catch the rebounds on the news the next day and dont try to anticipate a mid day of correction. Here is a pic of one day candles. Notice the bodies are usually full meaning price goes one way and stays one way for the day.

If you are above the Red lines you are in safer territory. The MA cross serves one major purpose. It increases your odds that when you enter, price is really going to change in that direction. BUT that does not always happen, sometimes it crosses and then continues on its trend and we have a negative trade. Then we get our infamous runner. All currencies during the year will have a run and go off the chart. We do three things to combat that. 

  1. We use a MA cross so that we wait patiently for price direction to change.
  2. We wait until price is at an extreme before we try to counter trend the trade.
  3. We use the 2.4.2 recovery system to zero out the runner trade and multi level the trade.

We had used a 3x3 cross and got into trades earlier but we also got involved in more runners. I think the 6x6 has helped us in getting out of those trades better. Anyway that is why we dont try to get in too early. You are countertrend trading and you must wait for that counter or you will be becoming a great expert in the 2.4.2 recovery system. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

  1. There is one more scenario and this is the benefit. If you are in the same 4H candle yes the EA will always reenter. However if you are in a new candle then all the lines have moved and on a retrace you may also get a cross back up and no reentrance. This does not happen often but it can and so you pick a different entrance later. This is when prices are in a very tight range. At first it seems crazy, you just seem to be paying the spread over and over again but total pip wise I pick up a lot more pips this way.
  2. Where the benefit comes is over a period of days where price action is going nowhere and you pick up 1 one day. 2 the next, 1 the next and then price takes off somewhere. It was an extra 40 pips I did not pick up before. Lets say price went against you and you have to do a 2nd level and later you zero out or take a small profit/loss trade. That is 40 pips you never would have gotten if you had just played the cross. That 1st level trade got you nothing but a loss on the books and your only profit came from the 2nd level. At least this way you got something from that trade.
  3. So lets say the MPTM picked up +40 but later you closed a zero out trade of -100 1st level and +100 2nd level for 0 but with the MPTM that series of trades bagged you an extra 40 which ended up being your profit on a zero out trade sequence. Clear as mud yes???
  4. When you think of trading I think of a trade sequence instead of one single trade win or lose. When I have a DD in a currency pair, I might end up with 8-15 trades before I am done. Maybe 40% are MPTM, 1 or 2 are losing trades and the rest were profitable. So the entire trade sequence is really your profit or loss. That sometimes is the hard part to grasp and understand.

For example I was into the AUD/JPY for most of the month on one big long trading sequence. I did 36 closing trades on it. Here is the breakdown:

  1. 21 were MPTM for 210 pips
  2. 5 were for losses for -484
  3. 10 were winners for +357

Without the MPTM my pip profit is smaller than my pip loss. (You must remember my losses are 1st level trades and they have the lowest lot size, so moneywise I make money even though I have lost more pips than won.) So with out the MPTM I am -127 pip wise (money wise there was a small profit) But with the MPTM I am +83 pip wise and sitting on a much bigger profit. Anyway that is my breakdown on that trade sequence.

If I were trading this chart manually, I wouldn't have entered yet. I'd wait for Red,White and Blue to be at extremes with price in bottom 1/3 ,1/4 of chart and then **confirmed divergence**. That is, you get a lower low with the next 4HR candle closing higher. I also have a couple other rules I follow when it comes to divergence. The divergence has to be spread over at least 4 candles but no more than 5 days. The confirmation candle has to be green for a buy and not a pin bar or spinning top with a tail pointing up. On the chart below, if that last green candle finishes green and doesn't finish with a tail up, I'm in at close. Why the two RSI indicators? One is a high and one is a low. Look at the low when your getting lower lows and the high for higher highs.

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

4 of each eur, usd, jpy  
_**aud/cad - aud/nzd**_ this matc hes minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.  
_**chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd**_  
_**gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy**_  
_**Alternatives:**_ the _**a****ud/jpy, eur/jpy,**_ are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the _**EUR/NZD**_ is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with _**nzd/chf or nzd/jpy**_. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

> [Quoting roachroach](/thread/post/3671593#post3671593 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Ok so let's say you were short on EURNZD with your 6x6 SELL EA ON. Even if you are short with this EA, MPTM manages long trades retracements? I thought MPTM only entered trades going the same direction as the EA applied on the chart. So basically MPTM will manage crosses either direction during your main/initial trade (only if the 6x6 is still on)? Am I correct?  
>    
>  If I am, I open a primary trade following your rules, and let MPTM manage zigzags/retracements during that trade to "scalp" some pips here and there, and it will never close the first/initial...
> 
> Ignored

IF YOU HAVE THE MPTM SET FOR 'TRUE' for manage all trades, it will manage all your trades. If you have manual trades it does them all. If you close one trade with a magic number, the EA closes all trades of the same magic number on that currency pair not the MPTM. If you have 4 trades going and each one has a different magic number or are manual the MPTM handles each trade seperately. Only when you have two trades using the same magic number will it close both. The MPTM does not close both trades but the EA does. That is why with Ver. 4 I have seperate EA with seperate magic numbers for each level. You handle each level seperately with the MPTM. That is why yesterday I closed that one EUR/NZD 2L without affecting the other levels. It is also why I am not getting my good separation on my levels because I am entering off of crosses and S/R lines instead of every 200 pips like in the past. We will see if this is a good thing or not. But I will take those trade off of S/R lines above the gold lines. Those are pretty safe trades.

You are not used to this so you have a choice. Close out and never use it again or learn to deal with this situation. GBP/NZD, GBP/anything will do this. I have played the gbp/nzd at times and gone 3 levels -150 or about 700 in the hole for L1 and ended up with a profit so. Count this as part of your learning tuition. There is a reason why I dont even list that pair, I only trade it when it is at very high/low extremes.  
  
The reason I teach multi-level trading is this will not be the first or last time you will find yourself in this situation. I have a plan. If I go 2-300 pips in the hole I reenter again. If I retrace to profit great. If not I will reenter again. The first time you this it scares the ............... out of you but once you get used to using it. Heck I find it normal. Yesterday I was over -2000 pips DD. Today I am -1600 pips DD but I pocketed another 1000+ in the bank. If you can master this and it will take time and you will take your lumps. You will find forex trading not stressful.   
  
I use the high/low EA or I manually input them at just below or above S/R lines. But you could use it. In my trading arsenal and I dont want to confuse the H........... out of you guys but I use a BB sometimes, 6x6, 3x3, 1x7, depending on how I am reading the charts. Once you get used to 6x6 you will look at a trade and say, I wish I could get in quicker now than the 6x6 so I use different EAs or if this moves up a couple more pips what a great entrance for the high/low EA. It will all come over time. I only tell you about my 6x6 trades and enters above and below the gold line.

Just to let you know I try to keep my ratios low so I can handle surprises without damaging my account. I trade nickels at 800 dollars this month and my return on one live account (4H system) has been 25%, one of my best months ever. I have used this EA for 2 weeks at .05 and one week at .01 and my return has been 10.3%. These numbers would keep your account with less than 10% on average DD and 20% when I was running my worst case DD. To hit 83% or triple of what I have done would mean in a worst case DD you would be endangering your account. Now if you have extra money to put in the account you can trade like that but if you dont then it is dangerous. I now have a rule that if my margin goes bigger than 20% of my account on a DD I will add more funds to that account and keep my ratios intact. That way I can run my 2.4.2 recovery system without being hampered by not having enough funds. So those are my rules guys in case you need to know. Those rules come from a lot of bad experiences but those numbers seem to fit if you trade at a 100:1 leverage. I hope this helps some of you with your trading.   
  
I just helped out a guy who had a very large account and was over 10% DD on just a few trades. I used about 20% sized lots than he used and I got him back to BE after a couple of days. So keep your account intact and trade wisely. Again nothing wrong with 83% return is you have the extra funds to put in the account quickly if it gets into trouble. But if you dont have a buffer then you will get into trouble at some point. I have 3 accoutns with IBFX. I trade 2 live and one has reserve money just in case. IBFX will transfer from one account to another in a matter of minutes if I need it. So that is how I trade and how I protect myself.

MPTM 6 DIGITS SOLUTION:  
  
Ok, finally found out a solution.  
Take the "MPTM BREAKEVEN EA", and change breakeven to 200 (instead of 20) and break evn profit to 100 (instead of 10). If you want to use a jump of 30 pips, change it to 300. Also, change manage this pair only to "true" and manage all pairs to "false". Save this new EA to "MPTM BREAKEVEN EA 6 DIGITS"  
  
How to use it? open a trade manually or with 6X6 EA, and drag and drop your 6D MPTM EA to manage your trade.

Kraven,  
  
As you are new to Forex and MT4, I would advise you demo just using manual trades first. Even if you use NB's system, you can trade it manually. EA's are fine once you understand what you want them to do, but they can be confusing if you don't know why they are opening trades. Better that you know why you opened a trade yourself, so that you can study it and learn how to close it out properly.  
  
Also, before anyone else says it, you should head over to babypips.com and take their entire course, you will learn about how much you do and don't know.  
  
One other thing to be aware of, at least it bothers me.... MT4 allows your broker to see EVERYTHING you are doing, including all stop losses and take profits on every trade. This means they hold all the cards. There are some EAs, such as the MPTM that is used here, that will manage your trade and hide this info from the broker (at least we hope it does).   
  
Anyway, welcome to the craziness that is Forex. Best damned market in the world, IMO. 

Disregard all prognostications.

First your spacing is good. Your at support that it good. Every NZD currency is at a decision point. I have about the same thing except I am only two levels deep. I didnt get that firstlevel. If price went below that support you would close level 1 and take it as a loss. then find a new 3rd level. L 3 now becomes tricky. If it is making a nice profit I take that profit because price will oftne go back to the support level several times sometimes and I want that profit every time. This is where I get a lot of my MPTM. So anytime I am sitting on 100 pip profit I take it. The slower currencies 50. Anyway the GBP/NZD has bounced off S line now 4 times. I havent done as well with this one as I have with others but I have gotten 4 MPTM and one profit of 50 playing off that bottom. When price is changing direction it can sit at a bottom or top for several days before really reversing and you can pick up most of your DD there. I did that with the AUD/JPY at the beginning of the month and acutally covered almost all my DD from those bounces. So when price finally moved down on that pair and I zeroed out the trade I actually turned a profit. So play those bounces off of the S line and see how many times you can pick up some pips. Once you get the hang of it you really relax as a trader. These things happen all the time and you begin to see them coming. You just dont know when and where but they do come. For me on this trade, I already have broken even and if price now moves up, I will make a profit in this series of trades. I dont look at trading anymore one trade at a time, I now trade the series of trades and try to come out on top.

Because none have the same magic number. That is why an EA has a magic numer so you can deal with more than one trade at a time. Since manual trades dont have one and EA only entered one L the MPTM will handle them all separately. I went through the MTPM code today and noticed it will set TP for you too. So you can use it for that too. The MPTM doesnt close all levels the EA does. If the EA has put multiple levels with the same magic number and the MPTM closes one, its the EA that closes the rest. The EA only closes the trades it entered with the same magic number. Any trade without that magic number will not be controled by that EA. So you can put manual trades on but without the magic number the EA willnot control them. The MPTM will manage all the trades but only one at a time. If it closes one it is the only trade it closes. If it is one that the EA is controling then the EA will close all the other trades with the same magic number and nothing more. So if MPTM closes a trade that is the only one it touches. The EA only handles trades it enters and attaches its magic number too. Manual trades dont have the magic number so the EA does not handle them. The MPTM will close manual trades, EA trades but on a case by case basis. Hope this clears it all up.

Hi Nanningbob!  
  
Thank you greatly for posting all your hard work and congratulations on the great result for April.  
  
I downloaded version 4 today and noticed a problem in the CloseAll script, just because I encountered the same thing today in the EA I am writing. (Which is not ready for the world yet!)  
  
Any of the cases in CloseAll that may skip order(s) i.e. cases 1 to 7, will not work properly if any orders are actually skipped. The reason being that after the skip, OrderSelect(0,SELECT_BY_POS,MODE_TRADES); would keep getting the same order again until cnt equals total and so not close any following orders that might need to be closed.  
  
The way I fixed it in my code was:  
  
change  
OrderSelect(0,SELECT_BY_POS,MODE_TRADES);  
to  
OrderSelect(cnt,SELECT_BY_POS,MODE_TRADES);  
  
i.e. replace 0 by cnt  
  
and add  
cnt--;  
total--;  
into the section of the code which runs when an order is deleted.  
  
\--  
  
This is my first post at FF so if I have done something wrong by posting a code fix here then please excuse me. If I come across anything else, should I post here or email you?  
  
Again, many thanks.  
  
David

You are trading too large of lots. Even at 3000 pips in the hole my DD seldom goes over 20% of my account. 

  1. Lesson #1 in trading, dont overleverage, will get you into trouble no matter what system you use.
  2. Lesson #2 When learning a new system never start with the volatile pairs.
  3. Lesson #3 Learn to take a loss. If my account gets near the 20% level of my account I am closing L1 trades or adding more funds to my account if I think the trades are still good.
  4. IF YOU CANT CLOSE A LOSING TRADE, YOU NEED TO GET OUT OF THE BUSINESS. YOU WILL HAVE LOSING TRADES. 
  5. I have a plan and I stick to that plan. Somewhere at - 400 -500 I am taking my L1 loss. I violated it on my last eur/nzd and took a bigger loss than I should have but I still closed it.   

  6. You cant be a good trader until you are willing to handle that bad trade and take the loss.   

  7. Being 50% down is not the trading systems loss. You violate the rules you gonna get burned in this business.

In American money that is 5 cents not 50 cents. 50 cents would be way too much. So if I get 100 pips I make 5 dollars. 4000 pips about 200 dollars. My goal is to be around 8-12% increase of my account every month. Last month I did better than 20% but that was a very unusual month. I dont expect that to happen often. I take trading as an investment not a get rich or make a living thing. So that is my approach. Obviously 10% return on my investment every month is very much worth my time. As my account gets bigger I will lower my expectations to 5%. This way I dont ever blow an account and I trade very reasonably. It took me almost 3 years to learn this and it is very hard to get traders to understand and comprehend these numbers. They want to put my EA on the back tester and see if it makes them a million bucks in 6 months. Just not going to happen. Being 50% down should never happen. Lots are way to big or you are way underfunded. Again when I post my DD at 3000 pips I am still under 20% of my account. I feel if you trade bigger than that you are really asking for trouble. I hope that is understandable.

FOR ALL THE PEOPLE WHO ARE UNSURE of lot sizing with this system. As a general rule NORMALLY you should use 1/50000 to determine your lot size (e.g. if you have $1000 divide by 50000 you get 0.02 as lot size). This is for lower time frames with Stop loss of around 25 pips.   
  
HOWEVER, and this is very important, with higher Time Frames such as daily and 4 hour this should be 1/500,000 to 1/200,000. For instance BOB is using $1,000 divided by 200,000 = 0.005, which is 5 cents a pip. Unless you are willing and able to top up your account anything more is pointless.  
  
If you read BOB`s instruction book regarding 2-4-2 recovery you can see that you may need around 1200 pips for one trade, now imagine there are 3 trades at the same time. That is 3600 pips down plus you have to have a balance to cover your margin. The maths does not add up. As BOB says this is not a get rich quick but a slow and steady system.  
  
Good LUCK

Why do I trade a 4H chart. It is because it tells a story. Here is the story it is telling about the usd/chf. If you notice in the last 8 weeks. The usd/chf goes to its high or low aound wed or thurs and then retraces. It has done this 8 of the last 8 weeks. Now is it guaranteed to do that this week again? No, of course not but that is how I will play it. The odds are in my favor. One nice retrace and I end up with a profitable trade. And we all are happy. If not I have a back up plan. That is how I trade and try to teach. Look at this pic. the dotted lines divide the chart by weeks, the solid lines show the turnaround spot every week. I will play this consistancy. The 4H chart speaks and tells a story, learn to read the story it is telling you.

hi I encountered the same when I first loading the "6x6 BE Jump" template.  
  
This what I did:  
  
For MPTM overwriting with NB-iBreakeven issue:  
\- Right click & select "Indicators List" or Control+I ;   
\- Double click on NB i-Breakeven and set the "Corner" to "1"  
\- Press ok and done, the breakeven info will appear in Top Right Hand Corner  
  
Note: Corner 2 = Bottom left  
Corner 3 = Bottom right  
  
For NB-iExporure showing "unknown" trades:  
\- Right click & select "Indicators List" or Control+I;  
\- Double click on the NB iExposure, don't change anything and click "OK" to close it;   
\- Done and now it shd show only your trades  
  
Hope it helps

The UK is in trouble but the USA has assets where the many countries in Europe have little in assets left. They have already borrowed beyond what they are worth. The USA has the four things that will be desperately needed in the future. Food, water, its own energy supplies and is still rich in resources. However, the key is going to be how fast we can get out from an oil based economy. We will need other energy sources to sustain our level of living. The present recovery will get choked every time by the rising price of oil as its demand goes up by expanding and recovering economies. There simply is not enough to go around. This will spike the price of oil and that will stall the economic recovery. Remember price spiked to over 140 a barrel right at the economic collapse. Not many people write about this but it was a major contributing factor to this recession. First country that gets out of the oil based economic system gets to enjoy a great future. There are just too many underlying fundamental problems for this all to go away quickly.

A hedge is an emergency stop trading. In other words you are caught in a super news story and everything is going against you. You are looking at a large loss and you know it is going to get worse. You have two choices, take a loss that may take you weeks to recover from or you can freeze time where you dont make money and you dont lose money. The news story plays out and then you can go back to regular trading and reduce your debt.   
  
Lets say your DD is at -2000 and a super news story hits that could send you to -5000. Instead of taking a -2000 SL you freeze time with a hedge or you can try to ride out a -5000 DD. With a hedge, two days later you close out your proft trades and subtract the same amount from your DD. then deal with your -2000 DD from a couple of days ago. In other words you only trade the market when it suits you not the other way around. It gets you past the bad trades that are really going bad. You keep the trades that are going good. You caught the wave of the news story and hedge the ones going bad. That is the value of hedging. You trade the market only when it is ranging the way you like.   
  
A managed account I am doing was at -1274 DD on all the trades. I knew news was going to make the market go nuts. So I hedged all the trades. The market could have sent the DD into thousands in the hole but during that whole mess the DD never moved. Now I have -1274 DD which consists of -1704 in losses and +430 in profit. I will look at the trades Monday, the news Monday and see if I want to start trading again or sit on these hedges. I can now wait this entire news story thing out. The guys here know I can handle a -1274 DD pretty easy. I had one inverstor write me and tell me, hey you avoided the blood bath. I know one guy who tried to trade these moves and lost over a 1000 dollars in less than an hour. He was trading fifty cent lots. That is the value of hedging, you make everything equal, walk away and while everyone else is having a heart attack, my blood pressue didnt rise 1 point. I will read the news over the weekend, wait for the monday gaps and then decide whether the market has settled enough for me to trade. If it isnt and the market is going to go nuts again next week. I will sit on my hedges while everyone else is pulling their hair out. At some point the market will return to normal. I will take a couple of trades above below the gold lines and my DD will be gone. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) That my friend is the value of hedging.

You have two choices, take a loss that may take you weeks to recover from or you can freeze time where you dont make money and you dont lose money. The news story plays out and then you can go back to regular trading and reduce your debt.   
>    
>  Lets say your DD is at -2000 and a super news story hits that could send you to -5000. Instead of taking a -2000...
> 
> Ignored

I dont know if anyone is making a living trading. Trading is more of investment to me. If you try to make a living you get into a concept of I have to make xx dollars a week or month and you put this artificial pressure on your self to always increase your account. That is simply not reasonable. No system wins every month but you want a system that is consistent over a period of time. Second if your not making your amount you want to make everyweek you have a tendency not to close a losing trade scenario. During this news market I stop trading because I want to keep my investment. I dont need to keep trying to trade to make an income. So my attitude is different. I dont need to trade this month if I dont like the market moves I can sit out and wait for the market to be more favorable. If you want an income you are desperately looking for something that will make money so you can keep trading. That is the difference. If you are looking for a steady income I dont think trading Forex is a good ticket. If you are looking for investment returns and are patient to wait out the bad times Forex can bring you better returns than other investments. To me that is the difference and how I think. During a years time the market will range 70-75% of the time, perfect for my trading systems. 20% of the time it is trending and I try to survive those runs, which I usually do. Then there are times 5-10% when the market is driven by news, like now, and my system is not good during those times, in fact no system is._**If you dont know how to trade the news you will get killed during these periods.**__**I admit I am not a good news trader**_ so I have found out the hard way to just sit and wait these periods out. If you trade for investment taking a month or a couple of weeks off, like I did last December is not a problem. If you want a steady income you feel this false pressure to trade and get killed during these times. Unless you are a good news trader you are looking for trouble to trade during these weeks dominated by Euro bad news. So to me the best way to trade right now is to sit on your hands or hedge your trades until the market settles back down again.

Dear Bob  
  
If anyone had any doubts about your trading system / philosophy the events of the last two weeks should have settled their doubts once and for all. The system was put to the test and it passed with flying colours. Movements of 300, 400 or even 600 pips were in abundance. Many of us were facing large DDs and were quite anxious. Some people cut their losses, some stuck to the system religiously and rode the storm, and some people did half and half. Needless to say the second group were the winners. I belong to the last group and with hindsight wished that I had kept my nerves.  
  
The lesson I learned from the whole saga was to realize the weak link in my trading is not the system, indicators, brokers, etc. The problem lies with discipline and psychology of trading and controlling my emotions. All of these with a $1k account and $250 DD. I dread to think of what would have been my trading behaviour if it was a $10 account and DD of $2.5K or even worse $100K account with $25K DD. I do not think my case is unique in FF. Reading people’s writings here in FF I gather most people are very much like me (i.e. mid income, full time job, Mortgage, pension, investments, family commitments, etc), trading small amounts we can lose and hoping to master forex with a view of investing more substantial sums when we are confident of success.   
  
Whilst we are concentrating on technical aspects we are neglecting the most important aspects of trading psychology. The title of this post is "Top 4 things successful traders do" which is an article in investopedia and can be found here ( [http://www.investopedia.com/articles...tner=fxweekly5](http://www.investopedia.com/articles/forex/09/5-important-forex-attributes.asp?partner=fxweekly5)). Please read it and follow the links also. I found it quite helpful, hope you do to.  
  
Bob as our guru and an experienced trader your guidance is very much valued. I would be grateful if you could give us your input. Another topic which we need your help is the use of hedge in situations we experienced couple of weeks ago. I would be grateful if when the opportunity arises you show us an example of how this recovery is done. My apologies for such a long and boring post.  
  
Kind Regards

I think I know what is going on here. When you change the lots you must go into the code and make the changes. Then compile the change. Then drag the new saved EA on the screen and save the template. Then set up all the currencies you want to do and save the profile. I have found out the hard way that MT4 goes to the last saved screen if something goes wrong or even when you just close it out and reverts back to the .07 lots size. If you dont change the template the template has the old saved version at .07 and that needs to change too. Then if your MT4 crashes or your computer crashes MT4 will go back to your last saved default. I got hit with some losses last year when I had to restart my computer and the EA started trading from some older version I used to use. So if you ever change your EA change your template and if you make major revisions safe your profile and resave the default. I once had an update crash my MT4 and it reverted to the default profile and I had a whole different EA system there. Screwed everything up. So now what ever I am trading I am trading off of the default profile setting and I have not had any problems like this since.

I am going to have to come up with some unhedging rules. I tried to unhedge the trades Friday and ended up making the problem worse. I finally just closed and took my losses. Clearly you cannot unhedge until the market turns back to normal and proves it has. I thought I had the gbp/usd and usd/chf topped and bottomed out and it ran Friday night and Sunday night. This caused me to just close out and take the loss rather than risk wiping out an account. Of course then the market reversed but I couldnt risk it at that point. So you have to wait for the cross to enter the countertrade and close out the profitable hedge. So I definitley have one rule. You have to wait until the full news run is over. Trying to unhedge before that can lead to disaster. I wish now I had sat on the hedge for another week or two. Bad decision on my part and took some losses I really didnt need to take if I was willing to wait another week or so. I am still not sure if the gbp and chf are done with their runs yet. I will be very happy when this Euro thing is done but it may last all summer and into the fall. If it continues I am going to go to a very small set of currencies that arent strongly affected by Euro news and stay with them for the summer.

Here is the dilemma I see. We have a good system that works over a long period of time. It has one weaikness the super news story. Now in Oct. 2008 we had two big news stories and then the markets went back to sorta normal. The two stories was the trillion dollar bailout and the interest rate change which was a biggie. Ok you could see them coming.  
  
This is different. Greece is going bankrupt. Bailout, no bailout, bailout, some countries threaten to pull out of the Euro, some other countries may face bankruptcy, maybe they need a bailout too, one country wants to do this, another that, .................... and so on. The problem I am seeing is a big super story can come from several different directions at any given time. One thing I read on the news which I did not know until days later but affected the markets greatly when it happened was this. The minister from France at the meeting threatened to pull out of the Euro if all the countries did not get on board of this package. Well, of course that would send the market into a tizzy. The problem is I didnt get to read about that until several days later and then I am already in the hole. That leads me to the next problem, it can happen again at any time in this atmosphere or it may not happen at all. I want you guys to know at this time I dont know if trading is really a good idea other than using MA crosses and going with the flow and forget all the rest of the other indicators. There are just some news stories we are not going to get until its too late. This is not like OCT. 2008 where you knew a big story was coming, it may hit without warning. Dang I loved April and hate May.

Buy on the bottom and sell on the top. If price goes against you around 200 pips you can set up a second position by using the 2ndL and countertrade the first Level. You can also use a third level 200 pips later again. I used to automatically reenter at -200 but now I reenter at a retracement around -200. ML is main level, 2ndL is second level, 3rdL is 3rd level. I do not recommend going more than 3 levels on a trade because then you are getting into martingaling and you can wipe out your account at some point. 3 levels deep is all I ever go. See info on the 2.4.2 recovery.

Hi Bob,  
  
Of course there will always be some price retracement when the trade is entered! In my opinion, I would master or at least learn the Manual system before doing any EA. That way you UNDERSTAND what is going on and how deep of doodoo you are in and what can happen next if you let the 'drain my bank account EA' continue.   
  
However, it can also be the 'make my account bigger EA' if you are lucky so it depends on the day.  
  
I think the key thing to understand that in my opinion there are three very profitable and popular strategies in forex:  
  
Trend direction systems, you can find them as usually in the first post it says, "Trend is your friend"... They probably made a lot of money in MAY!  
  
Ranging systems - THIS ONE.... You do good on ranging, but could get hurt when the market trends hard. However, it does't do that as often as some would like or not like. Example is I am working on an EA for 5M and in markets like this you make a killing.... However, in a trending market it blows up again and again... I am up 2K on a 2K account in about 3 days trading (demo, ECN).  
  
Breakout systems - london breakout, or anything w/ breakout... ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
I think they are all good and in my opinion it might not be a bad idea to do all 3. That is where I am headed.   
  
With Bob's system w/ 200 pip entry differences and such, it keeps you out of most of the bad stuff unless the move is ultra-big... like May... Or October of last year or December... Bob is smart and experienced with this management style, so do what he says and I believe you will make money. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
In other words, I would stick to this if you like the 4H trading and can trade longer term. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Aloha!

You can set it to manage a magic number. So if an EA has a magic number of 5 then you set the MPTM to manage magic number 5, it is only suppose to manage those trades with the magic number of 5. This allows other EAs with different magic numbers and manual trades not to be touched. The code is set up that way but I have never tried using those features.   
  
I have manual traded along with EA trade but my manual trades usually get into more trouble than my EA trades. I also use different types of EA. Sometimes I feel price will reverse and when it does it will go strong so I will use a 1x3. Volatile currencies I am testing a 1x10 and so far it seems to do better than a 6x6. The 1x6 is having the same problems I had with the 3x3 and that peeker trades creep in. A peeker trade enters and then price reverses on you. It just qualifies and then continues its trend. The 6x6 has fewer of those but the 1x10 looks good in testing on volatile currencies.

Same thing as turning the EA on and off. You just enter the time. Regular news stories do not affect my system. It is the super news stories that happen and you dont know about them until after the fact. The last news story was all over the news but the key part was not known until several days after. IE France threatened to move out of the Euro if the rescue package was not accepted. This was not reported until several days later. This caused the market to shift significantly along with people's opinion about the package. No EA is going to help you at that time, you are already in or out of that story. When I mean a super news story I mean something like the Euro collapsing or countries pulling out. That is not part of the normal news cycle. Normal news cycle stories do not affect my 4H system. They are just part of it.

This is like a non automatic version of that one now. They both are based on the 6th indicator but this system filters trades by using the RWB indicator for signals to go in or out and a MA cross. The other enters automatically at certain levels. The strength of the other one is you get a lot more trades. Under normal market news stories and ranging markets it will work great. It will have trouble with long trend moves and super news stories.  
  
This one tries to filter out the long trends and news stories by waiting for the MA cross. This system will filter out more of the bad trades but you wont get as many. What really makes this system work really well is the MPTM. I am working on version 5 now which will give you the one trade and either profit or hit the MPTM at +10. That is showing some promise. However, you still have to think and trade to use this system and too many traders want the easy way out and use an AUTO EA so they dont have to think.  
  
Also, many of the guys here are using divergence on RSI to trade with this system and they are doing very well also. Fewer trades but much less risk.

GBP/CHF, EUR/GBP, EUR/CHF (I dont trade this one too slow). I would avoid any European currency with the USD unless you are going strong on the USD. BERLIN (MNI) - The German Constitutional Court is weighing the possibility of imposing an interim order against Germany's participation in the E750 billion EU/IMF fiscal rescue package, German weekly Der Spiegel reported Sunday.   
The magazine cited a letter from the President of the Constitutional Court, Andreas Vosskuhle, to, amongst others, the German government, the European Central Bank and the Bundesbank. The case involves a lawsuit filed against the rescue package by Peter Gauweiler, a lawmaker from Chancellor Angela Merkel's center-right CDU/CSU bloc.   
An interim order by the court could temporarily forbid the German government from mobilizing the loan guarantees proposed under the EU package, Der Spiegel said. Germany's share of the EU measures amounts to up to E148 billion in guarantees.   
According to the magazine, the German government in a statement to the Constitutional Court has warned that an interim order could lead to "a self-fulfilling expectation of a default" by fiscally ailing EU member states.   
Moreover, the government remarked that the EU rescue package "is not a legally binding agreement under international law but only a political declaration of intent."   
In addition to Gauweiler's lawsuit, three others have been filed at the Constitutional Court against the rescue package. Another lawsuit is to be filed next week, the magazine wrote.

The MPTM must also be set for a 5D broker also so check that first. I have demoed several companies and some will get this more than others. I have quit using the jump function and only use the BE function. I just didnt get enough to justify its usage or lots of error messages. In other words if it doesnt hit the +10 I will usually get the +50 or +100 and seldom got the inbetween.  
  
From reading the MTPM forum I think the problem is too many messages being sent to the server at once. For example you may have one EA sending a Buy or Sell signal, The MPTM sending a BE signal and now your adding a Jump signal. If this is happening with several currencies at one time it maybe too much for the system but that is no a sure conclusion. Once the sever sends the trade context is busy or some other message back it backs up all the signals. Just my best guess on that one. Some MT4 companies servers are better than others.   
  
I may try using several MPTM, I mean you only need a blank screen to use them. So set at one +10 @ 20, another at +25 @ 50 and so on. That may work better than the Jump function and using 1 MPTM. This way each MPTM EA is assigned one task to do instead of trying to handle several tasks on several currencies. That maybe the problem, one EA being assigned too many tasks on too many currencies.

Bob, on hedging...  
  
This is something I thought about doing, or have actually been doing a little of in one of my live accounts:  
  
L1 trade entered, market continues against me for another 200 pips (.01 lots)  
L2 trade entered, market continues down against me for another 100 pips (.02 lots)  
S1 trade entered (hedge of L1), market continues down against me for another 100 pips (.01 lot to counter the L1 trade)  
L3 trade entered at -400 pips (or whatever market says) (.04 lots)  
Market retraces + 200 pips (50% fib) and I exit all positions for healthy profit.  
  
So, my thinking I guess is if the market does continue against you, why not negate the first couple trades as they move against you more quickly. You have probably already said this, but my thinking is to hedge 1.5 times my entries. If the indy says to enter every 200 pips, then my hedge for that entry is 300 pips later.  
  
If you get a big 1500 pip move like early May, than it wouldn't be nearly as bad and you don't close your trades. You could go more levels due to less draw down and hopefully climb your way out of it... ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
What do you think? 

We are our own best indicator.

There are several ways to control risk. Hedging is one way of doing it. Instead of extra levels you can just hedge and wait for price to come back the other way and then unhedge your trade. Or hedge your trade and use future profits to get rid of the hedge. If you 1.5 the hedge then it needs to continue to go against you for it to work. If it doesnt then you have two losing trades you need to deal with instead of one. So 1.5 works if price continues against you and doesnt if price reverses and goes against your hedge.

If the EA is used for all the same levels all the levels will have the same magic number。So if one trade is closed the EA will then close all three. The MPTM does not close trades it just sets the SL, that is all it does. If price hits the SL then the EA will close all the trades with the same Magic number. If they are different magic numbers then they will not close. If you get into multiple levels you should take the EA off the screen then you wont have this issue. I use seperate EA crosses so each level is entered with a different magic number. That way you wont have that problem.

Bob nailed it. I was having the same issue.  
  
Long 1 EA Magic Number = 1  
Long 2 EA Magic Number = 12  
Long 3 EA Magic Number = 13  
  
Short 1 EA Magic Number = 1  
Short 2 EA Magic Number = 12  
Short 3 EA Magic Number = 13  
  
Set MPTM to manage by magic number, this means 3 different screens w/ MTPM for each magic number.  
  
I really screwed up today on my live account too.... ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
I was trying out another version and put MPTM on another MT4 instance and it goes by account, not by MT4 instance (which I didn't know) and it closed out most of my trades. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f641.png?v=15.1) Down 1/3 of my profit for the month which isn't a whole lot as I am still testing! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Won't make that mistake again! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

We are our own best indicator.

This is a countertrend system not a trend system. I explain this in my book. The difference between a countertrend system and a trend system is: a countertrend system you are 100% guaranteed a retracement will happen. In a trend system you do not know when a trend starts, when it ends, and how long it will last. If I take a MA cross against the trend on a 4H chart I am 75-85% sure I will get 20+ pips on the move. The ones that dont I can counter trade again and take a minimum or 0 loss on the trade. The only thing I have to worry about is the super news story (NFP is not a super news story). Greece maybe going bankrupt, France threatening to pull out of the Euro are (see 1st week or May), along with interest rate changes are. So I take the trade. NZD/USD mystifies me as to why I got that first level. Must have been drinking too much green tea.

I am not a Fib guy, I think that is a worthless indicator. If you put it on the chart less than 10% of the time price will bounce or hit a Fib line. In truth almost all Fib lines are only hit when the also correspond with a S/R line. So in my opinion S/R lines are far superior over Fib lines. I once changed the math on the Fib lines and found out that no matter what math I used for the 4 lines between the top and bottom (0-100), price would hit a line about 10% of the time. So I threw that indicator into the trash.

The penultimate sentence in your post is the most important aspect of your system distinguishing it from any other I have seen. I have not come across any other system where a plan is in place to deal with losing trades. Normally in any system losing trades are accepted as part of trading but here there is a specific and detailed course of action to deal with it. As long as the trader has good money management discipline (i.e. stick to lots of 1/200,000 or 1/500,000 x account balance for example if your account balance is $5,000 divide by 200,000 = 0.02 lots) and **LIMIT number of trades** , everything will go smoothly.  
  
Bob being an expert can handle a large number of trades being open at the same time, however, what I have found is that if I have more than 8 or 10 trades open at one time and they go in DD then keeping up with level 2 and 3 trades for recovery can become a bit of a hand full. I COMPLETELY DISAGREE with anyone who doesn't believe in FIB's... I make trades off of them (FUTURES WITH A LOT MORE CASH AT STAKE ON EACH TRADE) daily and they are very accurate. I think most people don't believe in them because they haven't been properly taught. Those who have always love them.  
  
It really doesn't matter, you can use them or not. Big guys, little guys, a butt-load of people use them and create a market dynamic because of them. I believe the reason that some s/r lines exist is because it is 50% of the move, or 61% or whatever...   
  
With this system, it is really based more off of ATR which is good as well. The currency tends to move so much over a timeframe...  
  
\---I like the 10 pippers! They are great for MPTM, but can experiment as well. On my 3K account (risking 2k) I made about 100.00 the other day on those guys as well..  
  
ASTRAL mentioned having the difficulty w/ MPTM closing out L2 & L1 trades etc.. What I have done is manage the MPTM by currency and have an instance of each, then I turn off the EA for that pair when it hits 2 levels. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
I am actually reading MPTM manual through again as I have had a lot of errors...  
  
Oh, and something I am doing that I think is even more interesting is that I have converted the EA to be a 2-in-1 system. Basically, I have an EA running normally in the right direction, but I have now converted it to run in reverse as well at the same time. So, I have one that bets up and one that bets down. I am betting they are both right! This is more for fun, but interesting to see how it plays out. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
This system seems to be more about MM (Money Management) than perfect entries.... 

We are our own best indicator.

The plan for dealing with losing trades is normally a stop loss. And for what seems like a typical profit target of 25 pips (from Bob's results listings), the stop loss should not be more than 10 or 15 pips. That is kind of tight for a 4 hour chart, but the profit target is also kind of small for a 4 hour chart too, more like a profit target of a 15 minute chart, maybe even for a 5 minute chart if you limit the trades to only the best setups.  
  
Why are stop losses not used in this plan? Seems like a personal hang-up about having a losing trade. This is typical for professionals like doctors, dentists and engineers, since in their professions making a mistake has dire consequences. They carry this into their trading and think a losing trade is a mistake that they cannot make. They end up blowing up their accounts and are the worst traders, as a rule. However, the truth is you only need to be right 50% or less to make money in forex.  
  
In Bob's document he shows a trade that went wrong in L1 by 200 pips, then wrong again in L2 by 200 pips, but then with a reverse martingale strategy makes it back to even in L3 with 133 pips (a stated one third retracement of the 400 pips, or maybe the 38.2 fib level, haha).   
  
What would have happened in this scenario with stop losses? Hard to say what the profit targets would have been. The typical profit target of 25 pips he shows in the results seems low, especially since he is expecting to get 133 pips in the last trade to make the recovery work. Anyway, say he was using 60 pips stop loss each time (10 is usually too low for a 4 hour chart, though it may work once in a while). So in the end it would be -60, -60 and +133. Even without using the reverse martingale strategy (a betting or gambling strategy) he would have been farther ahead using stop losses.   
  
You may notice that even with only a winning percentage of 33%, there would still be a profit after 3 trades. It doesn't make sense to be chasing after 25 pips profit targets with 60 pip stop losses though. The alternative of possibly being hundreds of pips in the hole only works with pocket change pips, unless you have very deep pockets.

Black,  
  
This is the way I trade this system and the way I look at it. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
This is not 'typical' type system and you have to change the mindset to understand it. It is more about money management than about good entries. With my futures trading, I have a 5 tick stop (50.00) and my TP's are usually 20, 30, 40, or even 200 ticks away dependent upon how lucky I am! This is where a tight stop is used and with a distant TP makes lots of sense when you make lots of losses, but 1 winner pays for them in spades. BUT, I am absolutely glued to my charts by the tick for 1 hour per day (NY OPEN) and it takes immense concentration and one can only do that for so long in one day before going f-in crazy.  
  
With this system (NB), you basically have a bunch of little tiny winners (20 pips, etc..) and some losers or DD (-500 pips etc..) which you then use Martingale to get you out of it. This doesn't take you being glued to the screen or trying to have to figure out EXACTLY where the pivot is, or most likely where you are probably wrong. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Very few moves are greater than 2000 pips, so, if you are entering LONG on the bottom of your screen, and it drops, you have a long ways to play with it to get back to 0. If you trade smaller time frames, then not possible and a big move will wipe you out.  
  
I love this concept as the brokers can't stop you from picking up hundreds of 10 to 20 to 30 pip wins while YES, you have drawdown and your L2, L3, etc. will get you out of that.   
  
An example would be:  
USDCAD   
L1 trades = 13 different trades at +20 pips, before it hits DD and you need an L2 trade at 220 pips down the road. If that L2 comes up and gets you back to 0+, then I rinse and repeat.   
  
You trade very small contract amounts so 500 pips is really like 15 pips on a 15 minute chart etc.. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
I love it because no screwing around w/ the HOUSE (broker). 

We are our own best indicator.

One of the reasons I post my ideas is to encourage innovation. Having said that all trading EAs are based on indicators and they all have one main problem. It is what I call the peeker trade, in other words no matter what you use as your qualifications there is always those small handful of trades that qualify and then price reverses. This happens in trend following EAs a lot and to a lesser extent my counter trade system. I am having this same problem all week with my trend following EA. A trade will qualify and then reverse fields. I already know whatever you come up with will have peeker trades happen. This means we dont try but that is the problem that needs to be solved. Solve that one problem and your a millionaire. Now there are several ways to handle these.  
1\. Take a SL (most common approach, death slowly by SL, the tighter the SL the more often it is hit. The wider the less often.)  
2\. Multi-level trade ( IE reenter at another position and zero out the negative trade but have rules to limit your losses if you cant)  
3\. Martingale ( keep adding until you win or wipe out your account)  
4\. Hedge (come back another day, week, or month and trade under your conditions not the markets) Right now I dont have a set a rules for this but am working on it.
